B000RPTQ1C|4.0|With Viva La Vida, Coldplay have finally realized the potential that A Rush of Blood to the Head promised and X&Y obscured in a haze of vapid soft rock. Chris Martin and Co. have always tried to be the next \\"important\\" rock band, and with a little push in the right direction courtesy of producer Brian Eno, they might have just hit the gold mine.<br /><br />The album starts out with an instrumental, \\"Life In Technicolor,\\" already a strange move for the usually verbose band. The song sounds curiously washed-out, but the guitars chime in all the right places and this minor opener, which almost seems like a throwaway at first glance, turns into something nearly epic. Martin's distinctive voice immediately comes in on following \\"Cemeteries of London,\\" and everything seems in order until roughly a minute in the drums erupt and the guitar ups the ante along with the distortion. And what do you know: it works.<br /><br />\\"Lost!\\" finds Martin in standard melancholic form, but the tribal beat underneath and squealing guitar halfway through announce that, finally, Coldplay has grown beyond the same old marching, piano-heavy mega-hits that \\"Speed of Sound\\" epitomized. Coldplay are trying out new things, and it has never sounded better.<br /><br />Martin seems to have grown up as well, reining in some of the more wailing tendencies of his voice and keeping it, for the most part, within a lower register than the falsetto that was previously beginning to grate. Ridiculously successful single \\"Vida La Vida\\" is a great example of the old merging with the new; at first glance, it is the most similar to previous Coldplay hits, anthemic and self-consciously majestic, but Martin sounds desperate and nostalgic, with lyrics that seemed to have come straight out of a medieval tale. The pulsating strings and orchestral timpani lend the track an appropriately grand flavor without mellowing into the bombastic balladry of old.<br /><br />\\"Violet Hill\\" is even better, making a case for best song on the record with a pounding drumbeat and a buzzing, angry guitar groaning to escape, but it's Martin's inspired, lovelorn vocals that make the track.<br /><br />From the arching Middle-Eastern strings on \\"Yes\\" to the gentle sitar-esque guitar line on \\"Strawberry String,\\" Coldplay have never sounded as adventurous as they do on Viva La Vida. If there's anything wrong with this record, it's the band's decision to squeeze disparate tracks together, like the My Bloody Valentine homage tagged onto the end of \\"Yes\\" that sounds nothing like anything before it. \\"Lovers in Japan - Reign of Love,\\" another two-parter, fails simply because neither section is strong enough to stand up on its own, the former lost in too many waves of sound and the latter a fairly mediocre piano torch song. Along with the completely unnecessary \\"hidden\\" track, \\"The Escapist,\\" which is essentially a retread of \\"Life In Technicolor\\" with vocals, it's one of only a few missteps on the album.<br /><br />From the triumphant, hand-clap-heavy climax of \\"42\\" to the jarring string work on \\"Yes\\" that stays with you long after the track is over, it's obvious that Coldplay have made something fresh and exciting. Viva La Vida is not perfect, and it's certainly not going to be the defining statement from the important rock band of the decade, but it makes a good case for maintaining Coldplay's relevance and proves that even Britain's most ordinary band can still throw a couple worthwhile curveballs.drumbeat and a buzzing, angry guitar groaning to escape, but it's Martin's inspired, lovelorn vocals that make the track.    From the arching Middle-Eastern strings on \\"Yes\\" to the gentle sitar-esque guitar line on \\"Strawberry String,\\" Coldplay have never sounded as adventurous as they do on Viva La Vida. If there's anything wrong with this record, it's the band's decision to squeeze disparate tracks together, like the My Bloody Valentine homage tagged onto the end of \\"Yes\\" that sounds nothing like anything before it. \\"Lovers in Japan - Reign of Love,\\" another two-parter, fails simply because neither section is strong enough to stand up on its own, the former lost in too many waves of sound and the latter a fairly mediocre piano torch song. Along with the completely unnecessary \\"hidden\\" track, \\"The Escapist,\\" which is essentially a retread of \\"Life In Technicolor\\" with vocals, it's one of only a few missteps on the album.    From the triumphant, hand-clap-heavy climax of \\"42\\" to the jarring string work on \\"Yes\\" that stays with you long after the track is over, it's obvious that Coldplay have made something fresh and exciting. Viva La Vida is not perfect, and it's certainly not going to be the defining statement from the important rock band of the decade, but it makes a good case for maintaining Coldplay's relevance and proves that even Britain's most ordinary band can still throw a couple worthwhile curveballs.
031606792X|3.0|This isn't a one-star book. It could certainly have been better - the characters lacked depth compared to the other books, for instance - but save your one-star reviews for books that actually deserve them. Learn how to criticize a book objectively, rather than based on whether you like who got the girl.    For what it's worth, I didn't have a problem with Bella being pregnant, or with Jacob's imprinting. The pregnancy was a surprise that made things more interesting. I don't consider the imprinting to be \\"sick\\" like some others seem to. It is made clear in the series that it has little to do with sex while the target is still young, so what's the big deal? Grow up!    Is it really so unbelievable that it was fate - that Jacob loved Bella only as part of some grander design that would bring him his true soul mate? It's a fascinating idea.    I thought the \\"sex scenes\\" were the right level for this genre. So sorry that some of you wanted graphic porn in a book targeted to high school students. I mean, really?    I would have preferred more fighting at the climax of the story; it did seem that they got off too easily. At least a couple of important characters should have died. Like many have pointed out, that kind of sacrifice was what made Harry Potter 7 so powerful.    I would also like to have seen an epilogue, sometime in the future, telling us a little about Renesme as an adult and her relationship with Jacob.    One more thing: if you're going to write a review, keep your nasty personal comments about the author to yourself. This isn't the place. It is ironic that so many of the unkind reviews here have such poor grammar and confusing sentences... their authors hardly have the right to criticize someone else's writing skills!

6305311463|5.0|Michael Bay's films are an odd addition to the Criterion collection, until you recall the Criterion Collection's mission statement reads \\"All we ask is that each film in the collection be an exemplary film of its kind.\\"<br /><br />Armageddon is ultimate distillation of Michael Bay and Jerry Bruckheimer's commercial action movie formula, a formula that they introduced in [[ASIN:B00004STUL Bad Boys (Special Edition)]], improved upon in [[ASIN:B000059TPN The Rock - Criterion Collection]]and finally, post-Armageddon, ran into the ground in Pearl Harbor.  Later Bay films like [[ASIN:B000BO0LH2 The Island]] and [[ASIN:B00005JPNO Transformers (Two-Disc Special Edition)]]are informed by this formula, but none of them come close to this masterpiece of 1990s action.<br /><br />As you almost certainly know, the plot of Armageddon involves a gigantic asteroid on a collision course with the Earth.  The only ones who can stop it are a rag-tag crew of oil drillers, who hitch a ride with some astronauts on a pair of fighter-jet space shuttles to blow the rock to bits with a well-placed nuke.  Sounds silly?  It is, and the film has a couple of winking acknowledgements of its own silliness.  Mostly though, the film believes in itself, and it is easy to become caught up in the (false) grandeur of the undertaking.<br /><br />Lots of people will bad-mouth this film, but those people are movie snobs.  Armageddon was one of the most popular movies of 1998, and it was a defining element of the popular culture of the time.  Ignoring it just because you dislike its style or story is to put on cultural blinders.<br /><br />Personally, I felt that Armageddon's most interesting cinematic characteristic is Bay's use of a kind of cinematic short-hand.  Much of Bruce Willis' character is defined by previous Bruce Willis movies, creating a kind of ready-made character who already feels familiar when he first appears.  Likewise, the sequences involving the military are largely understandable only because you know how the military acts in this sort of movie.<br /><br />But the best example of this shorthand is the character of Billy Bob Thorton.  At one point he mentions that he was formerly in the astronaut program, but dropped out.  There is a very short, perhaps less than 1 second, shot of a pair of leg braces.  With just this flash of visual information, Bay has established an entire history for the character.  Anyone who says that Bay is lacking in cinematic skills is ignoring his great gift at conveying information in a fast, visual way.  A great example of showing, not telling.<br /><br />This Criterion DVD has all the usual extra features you might expect, and they are as good as you might expect.  The DVD commentary is entertaining and informative, and Bay is quite open about his commercial and pragmatic sensibilities, such as the story he relates that a certain beauty shot of a car was included so that the car-maker would give him money to build a bizarre set that was not included in the budget.  Many of the cast members also contribute to the commentary; Ben Affleck is the highlight, obviously well trained from doing Kevin Smith commentary tracks.  Bruce Willis is as laconic as his reputation would suggest, but his few comments are sometimes hilarious.  This version of the movie is also slightly extended, with some scenes involving Willis' character's father, and a few slight extensions that add character beats to some of the minor scenes.  Nothing major.<br /><br />The second disc has lots of interesting features on the making of the movie, a collection of deleted scenes and a few bloopers.  Most of the deleted scenes are comedy bits with the actors riffing in character, and all of them are entertaining but it is easy to see why they were cut out.  The best blooper is an appearance by Michael Eisner (Disney's Touchstone division produced the film), who tells Willis that his casting isn't working out and the studio is replacing him with Kevin Costner.<br /><br />All in all, this is a fantastic DVD of a highly entertaining movie. Don't let the movie snobs shame you into not getting it.  If you enjoyed this movie back in the late 90s, you'll find plenty to still enjoy here.  It has aged very well, and, from a film history standpoint, this DVD set is almost a time capsule of the bloated studio action pictures of the time.highly entertaining movie. Don't let the movie snobs shame you into not getting it.  If you enjoyed this movie back in the late 90s, you'll find plenty to still enjoy here.  It has aged very well, and, from a film history standpoint, this DVD set is almost a time capsule of the bloated studio action pictures of the time.

031606792X|1.0|Wow, just wow. Um, how can I put this politely so I don't insult anyone? I suppose I can't, so I won't bother try to. Breaking Dawn broke, alright. It tore whatever respect I had for Stephenie Meyer into millions of pieces. That being said, there WILL be some people who like this, I was just not one of them. If you have read the series so far and have enjoyed it, give it a try. Having doubts? Read on.<br /><br />So what did I personally have a problem with?<br />1) The cheap, fanfiction writing that a twelve-year old could write. It read like a made-up story on Fanfiction.net that barely stuck to canon. Stephenie Meyer just threw it all together as fast as she could, tried to make all of her characters happy for the sake of her fans, making it seem cheap and forced by occasionally breaking a couple of her own rules. Only once did I have to look up a word in a dictionary, and that was only because I forgot for a moment. Vocabulary = far too simple.<br /><br />2) Edward and Bella have sex. They are eighteen, don't use protection, but it's \\"okay\\" because they are married. (Complain all you want about this comment; I'm eighteen and I don't think it set a good example. Not for the eleven year olds reading this series.) Not to mention the ultimate birth control being Edward himself, which later proves false as well...  The story changed from a sweet, teenage romance, to a typical adult romance immediately. The plot lost all originality and now borrows aspects from the 1980s bodice-rippers. Bella \\"pleads\\" for sex (direct quote); she tries to seduce Edward with fancy underwear; when Edward agrees, he destroys pillows, takes chunks out of the headboard, not to mention finally getting her pregnant (something Stephenie swore couldn't happen with vampires) How is this story any different from any other romance novel? It was flat out laughable.<br /><br />3) This book gives off bad messages. Bella is NOT a good example of feminism. She never has been. But this book really forced me to draw a line. As long as you have your prince charming, everything will be alright. Satisfy your husband, make babies, stay home. Be dependent and subservient.<br /><br />4) Edward and Jacob's encounter. Disgusting. Edward asking Jacob to father a child with Bella? How could he do that to his own wife? And why on earth should it be Edward's duty to ask Jacob to do this?<br /><br />5) Jacob IMPRINTING on Nessie? What on earth is going on here? He just got done saying how he was imagining Bella pregnant with his own kid, and now he has to explain that to his future wife. It was so obvious that Stephenie Meyer just did this so Jacob would have a happy ending.<br /><br />6) Everything seemed too... convenient. Just as it seemed that the fast pregnancy shortened it all down from nine months to a week or so. Just as \\"Nessie\\" would grow quickly and stop at a youthful age AND so Jacob won`t have to wait long. It's just TOO perfect<br /><br />7) Love shield. That's all I'm going to say. He just got done saying how he was imagining Bella pregnant with his own kid, and now he has to explain that to his future wife. 031606792X|1.0|Breaking Dawn was a big dissapointment. The reviews show as much. It isn't a good sign if a couple of hundred pages in you're finding yourself not enjoying the book. The fact that it's the last book is saddening because it's really a lousy way to end the series. Twilight, New Moon and Eclipse were not the best of the best when it came to fiction, but at least they were a good read and had a intresting plot. Breaking Dawn is just insane. My main criticism is that everything that happens is completely out of place, and has disregarded the other three books as well as butchering the characters in the process. Compare Bella, Edward, Jacob or any of them to the characters that were in Twilight. There's a big difference. Really so far the only characters i'd feel a liking to in the book would be Seth, Jasper and Jacob, and even the latter is completely messed with at the end.    *SPOILERS BELOW*    The main theme of the books is choice and sacrifice, dwelved even more deeply in Eclipse. Bella has the choice of been with Edward her soul mate, and as well as giving up her current life, also giving up her humanity. But she also has the choice of been with her werewolf friend Jacob, and having everything she stands to lose by becoming a vampire- children, family, growing old. In Eclipse she realises this all and it's consequences and makes he descision, she chooses Edward. That was what Eclipse was for, to show Bella she couldn't have it all. Well Breaking Dawn completely disregards all of this, even ignores it and pretends such an issue never exsisted. What was the point of even having the love triangle, the chapters about the harsh realities of been a vampire and newborn, and Rosalie's story, if it was just going to ignore it? Bella doesn't lose anything. In fact she get's everything. She has her godly looking husband, she has her own baby who is 'special' and who everyone loves, she's a beautiful vampire who's so powerful she can save all her vampire friends from the Volturi, the largest and most powerful coven of vampires, and believe it or not, she get's to have not only Jacob in her life but also her Dad Charlie who also 'knows' the truth. The point is that she becomes way too perfect to the point where you can't stand the character any longer. She's no longer likeable, you won't find yourself cheering for her, you'll find yourself shaking your head in disbelief instead because you can't believe one character could be so lucky and so liked by all the characters in the book. It's just insulting the direction this book went in and how much the character was changed. She's gone from been a smart, perceptive girl who stands up for herself, to nothing more than a sex crazed housewife! She didn't lose anything nor learn anything. I feel as if i'm not so much reading the finale to a romance as I am reading about a girls transition in becoming a housewife.     That's another thing. The pregnancy issuse, or as I like to call it 'The Mistake of Nessie the mutant demon spawn'. She should never have been created. I'm certain that Stephenie is going to use the excuse \\"I only said vampires couldn't impregnante other vampires, not a vampire and a human\\", she's probably going to say that since Edward was a virgin when he changed, and still a virgin when he met Bella, he still had junk in his trunk, meaning he could impregante her. I still think the whole thing makes no sense and is ridiculous. Vampire venom is strong enough to heal wounds and enchance the human body, as well as get rid of bodily functions such as tears, but it can't get rid of sperm?! Why would a vampire need it anyway? If a vampires 'dead' with no beating heart, and a female vampire wouldn't be able to get pregnant anyway why would they still need sperm? It's not like they'd need it for humans because to them humans are food. Another criticism if this turns out to be true. A male vampire can impregnate a human girl but a human male can't impregante a female vampire? Where's thefairness in that? Really I saw the whole 'Half human, Half vampire' only as an excuse for Jacob, Bella and Edward to all have happy ends, and for Jacob to still be part of Bella's life. It was a horrible over used plot, and the characters actions revolving around it were horrible. Edward asking Jacob to abort the baby and impregnate Bella without her even knowing? Does that sound right? So he's virtous enough to not want to have sex before marriage, is such a perfect man, but he's ok with taking a baby life, and open marriage? I feel bad for Edward, Breaking Dawn really messed around with him. The only characters who even appear to have any sense are Jasper or Jacob. Jacob because he can actually see how messed up everything is, and Jasper because he's actually annoyed at 'perfect Bella' when she manages to be the best newborn ever. If I was him I would have left with Alice and not returned. Get away from the madness before it's too late and they end up like Jacob.    I was expecting a happy ending. Not because I wanted it, but because fans kept mentioning how Stephenie \\"loved her characters\\" and \\"liked happy endings\\". I wouldn't have minded it. But I seriously can't handle endings which are so happy and sugar filled that even i'm sitting there not able to take it. It didn't have to be a total blood bath or depressing ending like Deathly Hallows or Sweeney Todd but would it have killed to have a realistic one? Maybe someone important dying, maybe Jacob going his own way to live his life somewhere else, Bella finally growing up and maturing? Instead we have a cute lovey dovey chapter at the end like a fairy tale, with the two in the cottage tucking their child into bed and having a romantic moment. We didn't even have a proper climax or fight with the Volturim who were defeated as quickly as they came and then even apologizing before leaving. That's like Voldemort suddenly turning round to Harry and accepting his offer to repent, it goes agaisnt the other books. NewMoon and Eclipse hyped the Volturi making them seem ruthless and powerful and instead they are made out more like a joke at the end who end up skulking away with their tails bewteen their legs. If you're going to have main villains then at least do them justice and develop them, give them more time then a couple of pages, and give them some glory. Really the book was a huge letdown for me. I feel Stephenie's liking for her characters effected the story too much, there was too much information to handle, and that the whole plot was just ridiculous.    I hope I haven't been too harsh...
B00005JPS8|2.0|This review is for theatrical release as the DVDs aren't out yet.  Besically this is your regular summer entertainment almost all the way. A superhero action movie done by-the-book. Main character (a weapons merchant/manufacturer) is caught and held hostage by generic bad guys, terrorists or just warmongers, it's not explained. What the viewer has to know is that they are bad to the bone. Their leader has plans for world domination. The hero secretly builds a powered suit of steel armor and escapes. In captivity he undergoes some sort of change of mind and doesn't want to make weapons anymore.    The conflicts in this movie are very simple and show opposing sides playing the game of escalation in which the former weapon merchant and genius inventor clearly wins.    Robert Downey Jr. (Chaplin) is expectedly very good, although I have a feeling he didn't have to strain himself very much playing the cartoonish Tony Stark/Ironman. He definitely makes the best from what he gets. Gwyneth Paltrow (Shakespeare in Love) is WASTED in a subplot which leads nowhere. At least her character (excuse my forgetting her name) gets lots of money from the Stark's company. Jeff Bridges (Big Lebowski) (another actor wasted) plays the company co-owner and, by the end of the movie, a giant evil robot, a villain whose motivation is money. There is also the general (another wasted actor, sorry for not remembering the name) who is only there to show that Stark has a friend and to prevent IM being shot down by american forces.    There was not a shred of good dialogue in the movie, except for several Stark one-liners included for laughs (some of them actually funny `tho). Special effects are cool and are the best part of the movie and prevent it from being a complete disaster. Ending is incredibly weak. The first 1/3 (or so) lets you expect something that doesn't come later. Stark escapes and from there the intelligence of the movie goes downhill.   All in all this is a good summer entertainment but nothing to ponder about after watching.

031606792X|1.0|Ok, so first, I don't hate SM. I really liked the other three books. I read them in three days. Not one of them in three days, all of them. And I've read them multiple times since then.    That being said, I sadly have to agree with the rest of the people who did not like this book. I struggled just to finish it, and the only reason I did was I can't spend 20 of my hard earned dollars on something and not finish it. I didn't feel the characters stayed true to who we'd been led to believe they were for three books. From the second chapter they were ringing false. The plot dragged. The Volturi don't show up until so late in the book that it feels like an after thought. It's almost like SM went \\"oh... um, crap forgot them... here a little bit at the end, there you go...\\" or something.     You might try to say I was influenced by spoilers, but I wasn't. I didn't even know about them until I logged on here yesterday, and by then I had the book, so what was the point?     True stories, stories people love and come back to over and over, are stories where we feel we gained or have learned something. People love LOTR because we see and feel what Frodo had to sacrifice to save his world. (Spoilers) Bella didn't have to sacrifice anything, and she certainly didn't learn anything at all. She gained immortality, a family, a child, the happiness of her best friend (who should have left her long ago, the way she treated him), didn't go through a year long bloodlust phase and still managed to maintain her human family. It's out of character with everything we've been told about this world. The same goes for the whole Nessie sub plot. Even with the Succubus thing she tossed in there, it was a pretty weak explanation of what went on.     I realize that family is an important aspect of life, but I really don't feel that Bella learned anything from motherhood other than how special she was. The whole thing seemed to have two motives: 1) Bella is special, more so than anyone before orafter. 2) Edward is perfect, there's nothing to compare to him. (If we haven't figured this out in the last few books we haven't been paying attention. It was overkill. The pages spent describing him [again] and his flawlessness [again] is an insult to the reader's intelligence.)    If the underlying message of the whole series was the \\"only way to be happy is to find a man and have a baby, do it even if it kills you\\" then that's great. But there was such a possiblity for a stronger message to be sent to teenagers (and all people, really) about sacrifice, love and life not being perfect.     This book is perhaps the most depressing end to a good series I have ever read, and I hope to never see its likes again.

B000E1ZBGS|5.0|I think that I've seen just about every version made of this Jane Austen classic. This is such a great and endearing story that it is hard to mess it up (although the Bollywood bad-acid-trip \\"Bride and Prejudice\\" came very close!) But director, Joe Wright, showed that he was up to the task, doing a great job of retelling the foibles of the Bennet sisters. Keira Knightley's Elizabeth is strong and reminscent of a contemporary feminist while remaining true to the mores of the period. Matthew Macfadyen isn't the best Mr. Darcy, but it's hard to come behind the magnificent Colin Firth who played the role in 1995 as if he lived across the road from Jane Austin. Brenda Blethyn (Mrs. Bennet) shines as a mother on a well-planned mission to marry off FIVE daughters. Rosamund Pike (Jane) is the classic English rose while Talulah Riley's portrayal of Mary is not the usual ugly wallflower. Newcomers Jena Malone and Carey Mulligan (Lydia and Kitty) make the best clueless Victorian \\"hoochies\\" ever! But the real treat here is Donald Sutherland as the estrogen drowned Mr. Bennet. He has masterfully executed an unexpected role for him, exhibiting a refreshing tongue-in-cheek patience. Dame Judi Dench, always in top form, makes the best Lady Catherine De Bourgh to date. Unlike the previous adaptations, here the viewer is not bounced back and forth between London and the countryside locations and the costumes aren't overly fussy, giving the overall production an understated lushness. I would love to see what Joe Wright could do with \\"Sense and Sensibility\\" and \\"Emma\\".
B000NDI3SK|4.0|As someone who watched it when it was first broadcast, and again recently, I still find it an enthralling documentary. It's a pity other reviewers have concentrated on the lack of both gee-whizz computer graphics and sound-effects, but they should realise that it was made in a not-so-distant time when people didn't collectively suffer from ADD, and had the ability to concentrate and think. Dr Bronowski's commentary is fascinating and riveting, and that's what it is about. TAOM is a brilliant educational tool which remains as relevant now as ever. And for those who have a problem with the title, well, to put it in your generation's vernacular - build a bridge and get over it. It's a study of the human race; not an exercise in gender appeasement.

031606792X|5.0|I started reading the second I got home from the midnight release and didn't put it down until I finished the novel about 7AM.  I was blown away - really, I actually laughed and cried and woke up my hubby screaming \\"Yes!!!\\" at least once.  Stephenie Meyer has done it again - this is probably my favorite of the 4 in the series.  I have seen a few reviews complaining about the happy endings and Bella's not having to give up anything.  Frankly - this is FANTASY!  Does anyone out there really believe vampires exist?  No - but it didn't stop us from loving the series (and, of course a certain vampire and/or werewolf...).  Nope, things don't always work out in real life just perfectly - but then again, perfect vampire guys aren't out there either, right?  And really, I do not understand the tendency some have to look for some deep \\"message\\" to young girls out there - this is ENTERTAINMENT, not a life lesson.  And besides - look how Bella turns out.  Some complained before that she was a bad role model because she was always being rescued, etc. - when she could not possibly have been otherwise as a mortal surrounded by immortal beings with super powers thrown in.  Now, she handled her change better than any known vamp, has a fantastic super power of her own - one that, incidentally, probably saved the entire family and their friends during the final show down with the Volturi - and now she's a bad role model because everything turned out RIGHT for her??  Yeesh.  The important part for me was that the characters all stayed true to themselves and behaved as they would have to given their individual personalities.  Great story, lots of unexpected twists and turns, and after all Bella & Edward had going against them, I was THRILLED to see everything work out for them. The Jacob imprinting on Nessie thing took me completely by suprise, but after I stopped going, \\"What?  WHAT!?\\" I liked it - Bella gets to have Jacob as family, Edward and Jacob finally get along, and there is a lasting bond between the werewolves and vampires that brings an end to their long-standing hatred of one another.  Meyer wrapped up all the loose ends quite nicely.  Now I just have to wait for Midnight Sun.....and for my 3 daughters to finish so I can talk to them without ruining it with spoilers!

Two extraterrestrial bounty hunters are dispatched to hunt down and destroy the crites before they can fully satisfy their insatiable appetites. B0000025T6|4.0|Twelve and a half years after the release of his debut, Greetings from Asbury Park N.J. and two years after The River was delivered, Bruce Springsteen gave us Nebraska. This 1982 record represented an abrupt change in direction for this most popular of American artists. Springsteen's new course was so surprising and dramatic that you would be hard-pressed to find adequate words to describe it to a fan who had not yet been exposed. Gone are the horns; gone are Springsteen's electric guitar solos; gone are the anthems. We are no longer cruising in Jersey. We have moved to the mid-west and we are running from murder. Rock music is replaced by folk music - not gentle folk music either, but, rather, sparse music that is roots-driven, edgy and minimalist. We have Springsteen, his acoustic guitar and his harmonica. There is no-one else. On his prior recordings Springsteen told many stories that were not exactly uplifting. He wrote of economic and romantic hardships. On Nebraska he addresses violent death, the narrator's longing for a time when life was better and suicidal depression brought on by plant closings. The bleakness is unrelenting. The narrator of each song is at one stage of despair or another. Some suggest that the final cut, Reason to Believe, offers some hope. I don't think so. These people may think that they have a reason to believe but in reality they are done like toast.<br /><br />If you love Born to Run or Born in the USA there is absolutely no guaranty that you'll appreciate Nebraska. By the same token, if you are turned off by Springsteen's \\"anthemic\\" rockers but enjoy, say, the moody cds released by Johnny Cash in his last years then this may be for you.. Nebraska doesn't represent \\"popular\\" music. These aren't background songs for a cocktail party! The record is not an easy listen. However, if you do play it you must listen. The power is in the lyrics.

031606792X|1.0|No, really. Zero stars. Maybe half a star if I want to be generous and credit her for taking the time to write this, but as it was 800 pages that ought to have been 200 at most, zero is more appropriate.    I was never a Twilight fan. As per my review of the first book, I found it laughable, juvenile, and sending out a horrible message. But I also acknowledged that Stephenie Meyer had potential to take this series above and beyond had she waited and developed her writing. Revised the drafts more often. Given herself several years between her dream and going to a publisher.    Because I'm a writer. I'm young, so not yet a published writer (I've not yet attempted), but I'm a writer. I know she loves her characters despite the fact that they all fall flat (with mild exceptions in Jacob, but even Jacob is an undesirable character when compared to protagonists in other YA novels). They fall so flat that you can't even see them as characters anymore. They're voids for your own 'pick and place' fantasies. You slide in as Bella. Your dream slides in as Edward. Or perhaps Jacob.    The point is that the main reason I know Meyer needed far more time to write this series is Breaking Dawn. Breaking Dawn, for all that I detest Twilight, made Twilight gleam and shine with potential. I write in my own original fantasy with, yes, my own concept of vampires (though they are not actually prevalent in what I do--just formed so in case they do appear, I know what I'm doing). The one thing I know a fantasy author should never do is contradict her own canon for the sake of getting what he or she wants out of the story. It proves to me that Twilight and its predecessors were nothing but wish-fulfillment. Meyer didn't honestly care that she had said vampires could not reproduce. She seemed to forget that Bella was phobic of blood. Within one book she had Bella going from disliking a young marriage to embracing it, and not only that, but embracing a child that was breaking her ribs and growing nine times faster than any other fetus. A fetus born (or rather, bitten from her mother's corpse by her own father) with a full set of teeth, mind you.    Wish-fulfillment. I honestly admit I wrote mostly wish-fulfillment when I started writing as a young girl. Who doesn't? So if you never grow out of that, Meyer's work seems like a masterpiece. Because, as I said, Meyer never had the chance to understand the finer points of creating fiction, her books read like any teenager's romance story.    Even fans will tell you that her characters, primarily Bella, are Mary Sues and Gary Stus. By Breaking Dawn, I think Meyer had fully given into the curse. Bella was not only the most controlled vampire (and a newborn one, at that!), she could outjump Edward, hurt Edward, run away from potential victims, and basically act like a hornier version of her human self. The Cullens and everyone else were surprised at her level of ability. And, of course, she had the protection shield up the entire time, even prior to becoming a vampire (and possibly the only consistent factor in all four books, so for that I applaud Meyer, even if this trait is just another Mary Sue quality).    Unfortunately, Meyer has never had to deal with a lot of criticism from major names and publishing houses. She was not rejected. She was paid a lot of money and given a book deal. The Host exemplifies the fact that Meyer sees herself as a serious author when in fact she still has a lot of growing up to do. I've been writing since I learned how and yet I still need plenty of more maturing before I'll dare approach a publisher. That Meyer is allowed to seemingly do whatever she pleases caused more than a small disaster in this fourth book.    First of all, she uses the word 'manfully'. I don't think I need to even expand.    The amount of 'unwritten' sex scenes in this book skyrockets. Just because they're married? Apparently. Personally, I'm all for actually writing the sex scene itself, especially if it'sbeen awaited for three books. Describing the emotions someone feels is as good as describing the actions, but all we get is the sign of a rape scene.    Oh, right. The morning after. Once again proving that she doesn't realize Bella sets feminism back a century, if not more, Meyer gives us the most horrifying first time you could ever imagine. Pillows torn up, headboard smashed, bruises all over Bella's body. Edward charmingly telling her he did all he could to stop himself tearing her up (which, again, I don't see as romantic or flattering--it's like dating a serial killer and hearing him joke that you could be his next victim if he ever loses control). And if that doesn't make you cringe, Edward angsts about what he did and Bella begs and cries for more sex when he refuses. Essentially raping him because he sure as hell isn't interested and it definitely isn't fair to test him. But has Bella ever shown any outright caring towards him and what he needs to do to keep himself sane? No.    Oh, and since I've just reminded myself, Bella's time as a vampire seems a lot less overdramatic than what Edward made it out to be. Constantly talking of how difficult it was. How they had to keep control. How it hurt to be turned. Bella seemed to experience none of it. There was only a chance in her self-esteem and a lot less whining (which was a nice break).    One of the reasons why a lot of people dislike the HP epilogue (to mention HP because everyone compares her, unfairly, to JKR) is that it tied everything up so neatly and predictably that for many people, it wasn't what they needed. The names of the children, for example, were a little too fluffy to swallow. But that epilogue, for all that people were dissatisfied by it, looks good when held up to the light Breaking Drawn gives off.    Breaking Dawn could have ended in about a half dozen different places. There were a lot of good points for conclusion. But, of course, Meyer pulled her usual '200 pages of plot' at the veryend, and unlike the other books, there was absolutely no plot within this plot. No real epic battle. Just a lot of staring and puffing chests. But, as I believed from book one, the 'mean nasty icky vampires' who always want to kill Bella or people around her are, of course, secondary to the focus of the book, which is solely Edward and Bella. I think the fact that Meyer threw just about every character under the bus, including Jacob, proves this. In fact, the first book should prove it. Meyer just needed to not pretend she was writing anything other than a romance novel. Cut out the convoluted plot and you can cut the books down to two and save people a lot of grief. Except that their romance is absolutely sickening and ill-conceived, so perhaps it wouldn't save grief at all.    Finally, let's touch on the Nessie + Jacob bit, as that has been a big bone of contention. Jacob the pedophile, is that what Stephenie Meyer wanted to portray? Listen, before anyone gets angry, I don't think Jacob is really a pedophile, nor do I think Meyer meant for him to come off that way, but, let's face it, a months' old (toddler-sized and mentally matured) child pats his knee and calls him her Jacob and she doesn't mean it platonically.    All-in-all, Breaking Dawn was exactly what I expected from her, but still deplorable. Moreso than the other three books, especially the first. I still wish Meyer had backed off and written them with more practice. I still wish Meyer would see the anti-feminist nature of Bella's relationship (which is bordering on the extremely abusive). I still wish Meyer would experience what all writers experience--a little bit of hardship to sweeten the pot. She just has the pot and she's taking advantage of it with books that are as far from good reads as possible.
0440234743|4.0|Grisham brings his page-turning style to a contested will.  Aged billionaire Troy Phelan commits suicide, leaving behind a questionable hand-written will and angry heirs (six kids and three ex-wives) who get nothing beyond their debts erased.  The beneficiary is Troy's previously unknown illegitimate daughter Rachel, who lives as a penniless missionary among the Indians somewhere in the vast wilderness of Brazil. Naturally, the greedy heirs and their unscrupulous lawyers contest the will (claiming Troy was insane), while the exector plucks an acoholic attorney (Nate) from rehab to seach for Rachel in Brazil.  Grisham provides adventurous reading as Nate braves storms, floods, snakes, mosquito-borne diseases and hostile natives while traveling up the Pantanal River in search of Rachel. At the same time, we see how low the Phelan heirs and their sleazy lawyers will sink to grab part of that $11 billion estate.  But lest you lose faith in human nature, some redemption is mixed in with the mounds of sleaze.     I like Grisham's page-turning style and legal adventurism, but felt finding Rachel was too easy, and he took too long to get to the tepid ending. Still, if this isn't the top Grisham effort, it still makes very good reading.

I just finished the book, and I absolutely LOVE it.   Sure, there's less romance and more dialogue in BD than in the other books, but you can't expect Bella and Edward to always have that much drama--Bella despairing over Edward, Edward's overbearing protectiveness, etc--in their relationship.  Meyer has portrayed Bella's journey to maturity wonderfully through the saga.   I especially loved Bella's transition from human to vampire. Although the turned Bella is physically perfect and graceful, she remains \\"so Bella\\". Charlie's discovery was also a huge relief.  In the end, even Jacob gets his happy ending. What's not to like?  Maybe Bella does get everything she wants, and it IS all too perfect. So? If I had to give any fictional couple a disgustingly happy ending, it would be Bella and Edward. They deserve it!

031606792X|5.0|It's true this book wraps up loose endings, but I can't imagine why so many people think that's a bad thing.  It's done over the course of the entire book, not in the last chapter.  I laughed, I cried with happiness.  I read things I'd predicted and many I hadn't.  And then, at the end, I sighed in contentment.<br /><br />The Twilight-reading world would be screaming if we hadn't had details of the wedding, honeymoon, transformation, and Jake's resolution.  We got to see the Denali clan, the Volturi make a nicely threating appearance, and everyone gets a happily ever after.  Is that so bad?<br /><br />As a society we are programmed from middle school to consider anything with a tragic ending \\"literature\\" and anything with a happy ending a trite fairy tale.  I LIKE reading books with happy endings.  Sometimes I'm in the mood to read Doctor Zhivago, but I also appreciate well-written books that don't end tragically.  That's Breaking Dawn.<br /><br />Reviewers are complaining that Stephenie Meyer is encouraging marriage at 18.  Hello?  She spent a great deal of time explaining that, to most people, early marriage is ewwww[...]  She also spent three books leading up to the circumstances that led to the marriage.  Bella and Edward are not typical.  Unlike most 18-year-olds, money is not an issue.  They intended for Bella to continue her education (even if it were going to be delayed) and there was no expectation of pregnancy.  I think it was a POSITIVE message, well argued on both sides.<br /><br />Also, why do people say it's anti-feminist for Bella to choose to keep her baby?  Feminism is about allowing choice and not judging the mother.  We were shown both sides -- Bella's unconditional love for her unborn baby, even at the risk of her own life -- and Edward's anguish and desperation at the thought of it killing her.  If anything, Bella is more assertive in this book than in any of the others.  Edward's always been possessive and protective.  Remember him not allowing her to do things, like seeing her friends at La Push or even just being alone?  He did it for love and because he was protecting her, but no one could say it was feminist.<br /><br />I highly recommend this book.  It's meaty, satisfying, and well-written.her friends at La Push or even just being alone?  He did it for love and because he was protecting her, but no one could say it was feminist.    I highly recommend this book.  It's meaty, satisfying, and well-written.

031606792X|5.0|**Spoilers Inside**<br /><br />I highly anticipated this book (probably most people who have posted reviews did as well). The book brought on several emotions for me which I will break down in detail. I will not recount the entire plot of the novel, only key points to make comments on.<br /><br />1. The wedding - the wedding was beautiful and I was glad to see that Bella finally saw her human self as being beautiful. It was nice to see Jacob back, but he did ruin the mood once Bella mentioned the honeymoon and that angered me. The wedding and reception were shorter than I would have like it to be, but there were more important story lines to explore.<br /><br />2. The honeymoon (part 1)- I thought Meyer did a fabulous job of conveying Edward and Bella's intimacy without being smutty. She reinforced the sanctity of marriage before sex which I believe is a fabulous message to young readers.<br /><br />3. The honeymoon (part 2) - I was livid once I realized that Bella was pregnant; and, honestly, it was obvious that Meyer would go in that direction from all of the foreshadowing in Eclipse and in Bella's nightmares. I was horrified that a. Bella wanted to keep the baby and b. she ran to Rosalie for help. I could not refer to the baby as such, instead I deemed it vampire spawn. I felt that Edward was a blubbering idiot during this section and I wanted to smack both him and Bella and tell them to pull it together.<br /><br />4. Jacob's section - I was so extremely angry and frustrated with Bella that Jacob's voice was immediately refreshing. His quips between him and Rosalie kept the mood light when everything else was not. I love that he matured in this section and was not the egotistical idiot that I once deemed him to be. I rooted for him as he took charge and took what was rightfully his - his postion as Alpha. I do admit that the imprintation on Renesmee was a complete and utter shock to me. Given the circumstances it is strange, but it also made complete sense. By incorporating the imprinting on Renesmee into the storyline, it opened up the communication between the wolf packs, allowed for peace to finally come between Jacob and Edward, and created a solid alliance between the wolves and the vampires. As for those who believe that this imprintation promotes pedophilia, I believe that they are misunderstanding the delicate balance and nature of the situation. Yes, Renesmee is just a baby, but no, Jacob is not thinking of her in a romantic or sexual nature. Jacob is first and foremost a guardian and a soulmate. He is not rushing her to grow up, but encouraging her to enjoy her childhood. Jacob will remain a teenager until he decides to give up his shape-shifting ways. Renesmee will become a full grown adult in just seven years and then they can live their happily ever after. For now, he is more a body guard and friend than a lover.<br /><br />5. Bella- Not exactly the transformation she had in mind, but her tranformation took place because it needed to and not only because she wanted it. It was nice to Bella finally believe in herself and not rely on others. I really felt that Nessie and Bella's relationship was not as close of a bond as it should be. I also felt that Edward seemed somewhat detached from Nessie, and not very fatherly. I was relieved that she did not have to hide from Charlie and that he was somewhat in on their secret life, but I couldn't help but think - what about Renee? She is barely mentioned beyond the wedding. Poor Renee. I was, however, extremely excited to finally see Bella hold her own and become a stronger character once she transformed. I thought her power was amazing and for once she was the one who saved the day.<br /><br />6. Renesmee - What an awful name. I get that it's a combination of Renee and Esme, but it's still hideous. I hope that fans do not become inspired to name their daughters after her. I did not want Nessie (a name even worse than Renesmee) to be born. I thought she would be an evilspawn that would destroy the characters I have known and loved. Once she was introduced, I, like the characters in the book, melted. How could you not love her? Yes, the Jacob imprinting was weird, but it gave Jacob a purpose in life and created an improved alliance with the Cullens and a reconciliation with his own pack. She was the key to pulling together the vampire clans to prevent the destructions of the Cullens. I really would like to learn more about her character and to see her grow...a Meyer spin-off perhaps?<br /><br />7. Alice's role- I was aggravated that Alice did not have a voice throughout most of this book. I enjoy Alice's character and thought that she really did not have much purpose in this novel. I was extremely angry when she and Jasper left, but I had a feeling they would be back. Alice quickly redeemed herself in the final chapters, but I still hold a slight grudge.<br /><br />8. The vampire clans - It was extremely interesting to meet the characters that had been mentioned previously but not introduced. With their help, Bella was able to become the strongest weapon in the group - for the first time. I thought the scene with the Volturi would have turned more violent and found myself somewhat disappointed that it did not turn into a showdown, but I was happy with the end result.<br /><br />9. The happily ever after - Yes, this story had a happy ending. Did anyone remember that Stephenie Meyer's favorite author is Jane Austen? Austen was also a firm believer in her characters getting whatever they desired. Meyer's ending was no different. The characters had conflict in all the books, but it was resolved. Any conflict, no matter how large it may seem can be resolved. Yes, everything worked out conveniently well and there is no longer discord. The overwhelming theme was not that you do not have to make choices in life because everything will work out for the best, but rather, love does conquer all. It is a universal theme - with love anything can be and is possible - isn't that a lesson we can all agree on? Instead of a bloody war torn ending, there was a peaceful resolution - we can only dream of this happening more in real life. Yes, everything worked out for our beloved characters. What else was to be expected? This was a fantasy, no, I'm wrong - this was a FAIRY TALE! How could a reader not expect all the pieces of the puzzle to fit together when all along it seemed like a fairy tale - the knight in shining armor, the damsel in distress, the evil Volturi...(Meyer makes several allusions to literary fairy tales). Readers need to remember that this is not a work of nonfiction. It is not a work of realistic fiction. It is a fairy tale and everyone got their happily ever after.<br /><br />10. I am going to miss these books and these characters. May they live forever on library shelfs and in the minds of their truly devoted fans. Bring on Midnight Sun!nd loved. Once she was introduced, I, like the characters in the book, melted. How could you not love her? Yes, the Jacob imprinting was weird, but it gave Jacob a purpose in life and created an improved alliance with the Cullens and a reconciliation with his own pack. She was the key to pulling together the vampire clans to prevent the destructions of the Cullens. I really would like to learn more about her character and to see her grow...a Meyer spin-off perhaps?      7. Alice's role- I was aggravated that Alice did not have a voice throughout most of this book. I enjoy Alice's character and thought that she really did not have much purpose in this novel. I was extremely angry when she and Jasper left, but I had a feeling they would be back. Alice quickly redeemed herself in the final chapters, but I still hold a slight grudge.    8. The vampire clans - It was extremely interesting to meet the characters that had been mentioned previously but not introduced. With their help, Bella was able to become the strongest weapon in the group - for the first time. I thought the scene with the Volturi would have turned more violent and found myself somewhat disappointed that it did not turn into a showdown, but I was happy with the end result.    9. I am going to miss these books and these characters. May they live forever on library shelfs and in the minds of their truly devoted fans. Bring on Midnight Sun!
0743298039|4.0|I enjoyed this book, but reading through the reviews I found some common threads among those who didn't enjoy it nearly as much as I. Here are those common threads and my thoughts on them, to help you decide if this book is for you.<br /><br />- Based upon some very good reviews, many expected this debut novel to be the next 'Jane Eyre' (or another one of their classic favorites - so nothing could compete)<br />- They wanted a fast-paced page-turner mystery (and this book, though engaging is not that).<br />- The saga of a dysfunctional family in a mansion was not what they expected (or wanted)<br />- It took too many words to say too little to many - and the beginning was slow.<br /><br />My thoughts:<br />1. The prose in this book is 5-star worthy.  Setterfield does know how to write!<br />2. The book reminded me throughout of some of my favorite childhood books  - [[ASIN:0689831412 The Secret Garden (Aladdin Classics)]] and [[ASIN:1416510885 Flowers in the Attic (Dollanganger)]] - but now written for adults.  Negative reviewers often said the same thing - they just didn't particularly like those books.<br />3. The pace of this book is slower - doled out over meetings between the two protagonists. It is not an \\"I can't put this down\\" type book.  It is, however, an \\"I'm looking forward to the next time I can pick it up\\" type book.<br />4. You can't help but not like, the main character, Lea and the biographer and the custodian of stories.She's a fellow book lover, as she says \\"As one tends the graves of the dead, so I tend books....Do they sense it these dead writers when their books are read? Is their soul touched ... by another mind reading theirs.  I do hope so.\\"<br />5. The story is engaging, the premise is different and while a long book --- it spans over 120 years of unique family history and several plots--- it's done well so each chapter is often a nice tale within itself, but with bigger questions still to be answered.<br />6. It does start out particularly slowly --- allow yourself the first 50 pages or so to ease into this book like you would a warm bath, before you write it off.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE: Is this book for you? If you're expecting a good read about interesting characters and liked V.C. Andrews as a child - then you'll probably enjoy this one.  If you're expecting a fast-paced page turning mystery instead of the interesting story of Vida Winter and how she came to be who she was and the relationships she had, then you'd best look elsewhere.so to ease into this book like you would a warm bath, before you write it off. If you're expecting a fast-paced page turning mystery instead of the interesting story of Vida Winter and how she came to be who she was and the relationships she had, then you'd best look elsewhere.

B000WGWQG8|1.0|The original book may do a better job, but this HBO production takes great license with the facts, to strumpet things up for a public who seem to need the violent and naked, or otherwise they turn the channel to something equally brain-dead.  Factually, there is nobody who can document so much of what's presented here as \\"fact\\" -- such as Hamilton and the Adam's cousin, screaming for blood, with twisted angry faces, as a Tory tax agent is tarred and feathered. One almost expects Walter Cronkite to step out from the crowd with a microphone, as in the old \\"You Are There\\" series.  It also appears to be a conscious effort to show the early American revolutionaries were no different from modern anti-global thugs throwing bricks through MacDonald's and Starbuck's windows, and carrying effigies of modern political leaders hanging from ropes while waving the Red Fascist flags.  The legitimacy of early American sentiments for freedom and self-government is thereby eroded and belittled, while modern fanatics are elevated inappropriately.  Or the \\"small\\" fact that two of the British soldiers at the Boston massacre actually were convicted, and one of them admitted to his lawyer that he was the one who shouted \\"Fire\\" (while discharging his weapon), and not one of the street mob. The erasure and clever distortion of those kinds of facts is exactly how a trained propagandists works, not to make big obvious lies, but to cleverly skew things in a particular direction, and also to highlight the rare event (ie, the tarring-and-feathering) to make it seem equal to common events (heavy-handed British thuggery against the population of the Americas) which are down-played, or not even mentioned!  With those kinds of factual distortions, how can any of it be trusted?  It cannot!  Oh well, that's modern film-making for you -- where directors and writers confuse their own aspirations for social change and \\"influencing the masses\\" with authentic telling of history.  Advice: stick to authenticdocumentaries, and keep fresh batteries in your BS detector.
031606792X|3.0|This book is so different from the other three it's hard to believe they are part of the same series. As a stand alone novel, this one is interesting and entertaining. As a conclusion to the Twilight saga, it is sadly lacking. The character realism we have come to expect from Meyer is not there. In the other books there was never a moment when a character spoke and you thought \\"Yeah, right.\\" This book felt like nothing but those moments.  The structure of the novel was different as well, and while the idea of hearing from different \\"voices\\" in the same novel is cool, again it doesn't fit with the other books and there seems to be absolutely no reason for it.  I am 23 years old and I have a daughter who is eight months old. I got married at ninteen. I graduated from college and plan to go back for a PhD later in my life. I am an artist. I absolutely love my life and would not do anything differently. That said, I think that Meyer's version of Bella's \\"perfect\\" life is dangerously unrealistic for young people who don't know what part of this is emotionally believable (Bella and Edward's love) and what isn't (the entire rest of the book).   I can't help but think Meyer's religious preferences and personal limitations got in the way of Bella becoming a fully developed character.
031606792X|3.0|***SPOILERS***    \\"The girl was a classic martyr.\\"- Jacob Black    These words, spoken by the only person who seemed to have any sense whatsoever in \\"Breaking Dawn,\\" pretty much sum up this book for me. I could deal with Bella's whining in \\"Twilight\\" because it was such a good book. I gave her some slack in \\"New Moon\\" because she had just lost her first love. She began to annoy me in \\"Eclipse.\\" But \\"Breaking Dawn\\". . . . Bella reached a whole new level of whiny, pitiful female. Like Jacob says, Bella is \\"a classic martyr\\"; she would die for Edward, but it never seemed romantic. Her love just seemed like a sick obsession gone terribly wrong. It's really unfortunate that Jacob had to imprint on Nessie because he was the only person with any sense in this book. I enjoyed his narrative the most by far, & I found it beyond creepy for him to imprint on Bella's daughter, especially given the age difference at the time.     Bella's pregnancy was possibly the worst plot point Meyer could have come up with, & I agree with other reviewers who have said that this story ended just a little too happily ever after. Take a page from J. K. Rowling, & stick some reality in this book. Sure, it is sad for characters to die, but it is worse to wrap things up so neatly. However, the book is not without its strengths. In the last few chapters, Bella faces death & plots to save Renesmee & Jacob, which is touching. She seems to have grown somewhat.     More than ever, I see these books as sexist & promoting the idea that you must be in a relationship to be happy. If you are looking for a good YA story with a strong, young woman, I would recommend Libba Bray's trilogy that begins with \\"A Great & Terrible Beauty.\\" That series is miles above this one & deserves the attention & sales that \\"Breaking Dawn\\" has gotten.
031606792X|2.0|So, one day earlier this week, I came across a spoiler page, and I, like many others awaiting the arrival of this oh-so-lovely book, could simply not resist clicking on it.     After reading the promised spoiler (and breaking my pact with my friends to avoid such temptations), I realized I was wasting my time. I wasn't about to believe that Edward knocked Bella up with some supernatural vampire baby who, when introduced into the world after only a few weeks in mommy's tummy, becomes the girl who Jacob is destined to be with. Forever. (And forever and forever..right Edward?)     I remember thinking, next time when you are revealing 'spoilers', try not to sound so much like a bad fanfiction story. Stephenie Meyer would never do that to us.    Imagine my surprise when I found that she, indeed, did.    Now, don't get me wrong, there were good parts to Breaking Dawn, the best probably being the part in Jacob's point of view. His dark and sarcastic humor was a nice break from Bella's general dramatics and frequent praises of Edward's perfection.     But there were many, many more bad parts to the story.    To me, Nessie seemed like the easy way out. It provided a gasp-worthy (main) plot line for the highly anticipated fourth book in the Twlight Saga, and was a way to remove Jacob from the love triangle so everyone could get their happily ever after. And in a sick way, they did. Like some Disney fairytale. This, in my opinion, was the weakest part (so I guess that means most of the book is weak), and proved to be more disappointing than I expected.     And then there were the many muddled messages that this book contained, or lack thereof. Bella is pretty much portrayed as this helpless female who goes from being an average high school student to a young wife and then a teenage mother. What kind of message is this giving the many teenage girls that flock to this book? I was hoping Stephenie Meyer would let Bella be independent for once, but again, yet another disappointment.    And the greatest disappointment of all, where were the shared themes? They all seem to be shattered in this book, and it doesn't really seem like the saga is connected at all.     So my advice is, if you haven't read Breaking Dawn yet, don't. It pretty much destroys the epic-ness of the first three, and makes the entire saga seem like nothing more than just another romance

The biggest complaint was that Meyer didn't send a good message to young girls. I don't know about everyone else, but I'm not taking advice from a fantasy novel. After reading this book, I didn't say, \\"Ok, I think I'm going to get married and have a kid. I mean come on, Bella and Edward did it at 18, so I guess I can do it at 13, right?\\"  Please! Who thinks like that?     Anyhoo, the book starts out with Bella and Edward's wedding only being a few days away. Bella is self-conscious about the new car that Edward is insisting she drive until she is changed to a vampire. It's supposed to be so safe that a tank could roll over it, and it wouldn't be damaged. Since Bella is accident-pron, this is a must.  The book then quickly jumps to Bella and Edward telling Bella's father about their engagement. He overreacts, thinking that Bella is pregnant. She isn't, yet. She does discovers she is on their honeymoon, after her period is five days late, and she's craving scrambled eggs by the carton.    There was a couple of gross parts in the book, like when Bella has to drink blood to keep the baby from killing her. I don't think I'll ever be able to drink anything red again.    Over all, I thought this book was the best I've ever read. I started reading this series about a month ago, and I was hooked. I've never liked vampires, but the ones in these books I love.    If you love the Twilight Saga, read this book!
0307388840|3.0|I normally have a 100 page limit on a book where if it doesn't pick up by then, I would put it down and consider it a lost cause. This book is really tedious in the beginning ... lots of flowery words and it just wasn't getting anywhere. Frankly, it was just boring. It finally picked up when Robbie, the accused, was marching home from a battle ... till the end. I have to admit, I never felt drawn to the characters at all in this book. I thought it was a superficial book, written in a way that you keep thinking it's a movie, peopled by people who just aren't real.     I haven't seen the movie, so I don't know how good that is. I figured out who was the antagonist early on. I figured out why Briony blamed Robbie for the crime and I figured out the ending long before it arrived. The saving grace of this novel is the World War II scenes and the nursing scenes that Briony described. I love history and that little bits of it really saved this book for me.     If you like books where people put on affected airs, you'll love this book. If you like writing that is long-winded and trying to be flowery and lyrical, this book is for you. Don't try to read this book when you're in a bad mood, because it will keep you grumpy (that is probably my problem). If you have the time to sit and read a book like this, I highly recommend it. If you're a busy mom like me, no, this book won't do. It just didn't move fast enough for me to savor.     8/3/08

B0018D4SHY|4.0|Fifty-plus years after budding blues singer Richard Penniman transformed himself into the prototype wild man rock `n' roller Little Richard, these seminal sides on Specialty retain every bit of their invention and abandon. Recorded in New Orleans with the rock 'n' roll pillars of Earl Palmer's second-line drumming and Lee Allen's muscular, swinging saxophone, Little Richard's best singles are as good as any rock 'n' roll records ever recorded. His outlandishly raw and seductive vocals stretched the microphones to their limits, just as his hammering on the piano often threatened to shake his instrument apart.<br /><br />The hits are radioactive elements of the rock 'n' roll lexicon, their radiance undimmed by fifty years of tribute, imitation and repetition. Starting with 1955's \\"Tutti Frutti\\" Richard waxed a string of scorching sides that included \\"Long Tall Sally,\\" \\"Good Golly, Miss Molly,\\" \\"Rip It Up,\\" and \\"Ready Teddy,\\" each invested with a level of vocal exuberance unmatched by his contemporaries. Even when he'd take a breath and drop the key below the top-edge of his range, as on the mid-tempo \\"Slipin' and Slidin' (Peepin' and Hidin'),\\" his voice remained edgy, and his instrumental battles with Lee Allen reaped brilliant rewards. Richard wrote or chose songs whose themes matched the newly acquired independence felt by mid-50s teens. Even with the lyrics tidied up here and there, the sexuality was hard to miss, and coupled with the brazenness of Richard's vocals (and Lee Allen's sax), it's easy to see how rock 'n' roll menaced 1950s Eisenhower America.<br /><br />Even with all this inventiveness, as early as 1956 some of Richard's singles began to sound repetitive. \\"Heeby Jeeby\\" and \\"She's Got It,\\" for example, borrowed liberally from their predecessors. Later in the year, Richard's label head, Art Rupe, maneuvered him into the title song of \\"The Girl Can't Help It,\\" written by Bobby Troup. The production retains the New Orleans phrasings and edgy vocals of Richard's earlier sides, but adds stagey background singers. Richard still had plenty of thrills in him, however, laying down \\"Lucille\\" and \\"Jenny Jenny\\" to fill out the year. In between he dropped the Lloyd Price styled ballad \\"Send Me Some Lovin,\\" penned by Price's brother, adding dynamics to accommodate a bluesier tune.<br /><br />The rock 'n' roll blast furnace was stoked again in 1957 with the raucous \\"Keep A-Knockin',\\" but shortly thereafter Richard quit the business to attend bible college. His vacillation between preaching and rocking (that is, the sacred and the profane) prompted Specialty to issue older sides as new singles in 1957, charting his last U.S. hits with 1955's \\"True Fine Mama\\" and 1956's \\"Good Golly, Miss Molly.\\" A pair of tin pan alley standards, \\"Baby Face\\" and \\"By the Light of the Silvery Moon,\\" hit the U.K. top-20 in 1959, but it wasn't until he returned to touring in 1962, and found fans in the Beatles, that he once again placed himself on the U.K. chart with 1964's \\"Bama Lama Lou.\\" Filling out the CD are surprisingly sedate covers of Leiber & Stoller's \\"Kansas City,\\" and one of Richard's original Specialty audition demos, the blues \\"Baby.\\" Closing the disc is a live medley from 1964 that gives listeners a sense of Richard's commanding performance, even as his band played more soulful than New Orleans raw.<br /><br />This set's extras are interesting, but don't compare to the visceral brilliance of the singles, all of which have been available on numerous vinyl and CD collections over the years. Specialty's 1991 release for example, \\"The Georgia Peach,\\" offers the same hits with a different selection of bonuses, and Great Voices of the Century's \\"Rip it Up: The Hits and More 1951-1957\\" offers a broader view that includes sides from RCA and Peacock alongside the requisite Specialty recordings.  This latest set comes in a tri-fold digipack featuring excellent full-panel photos and an insert booklet with more photos and liner notes by Billy Vera.This is a terrific one-disc shop for those who want a focused introduction to Little Richard's best-loved Specialty sides. 4-1/2 stars, if allowed fractional ratings. [2008 hyperbolium dot com]p for those who want a focused introduction to Little Richard's best-loved Specialty sides. 4-1/2 stars, if allowed fractional ratings. [2008 hyperbolium dot com]
031606792X|1.0|I discovered Meyer's Twilight Saga only two weeks before the release of \\"Breaking Dawn\\". Though books 1-3 aren't entirely flawless I still was very impressed with the rich characters she portrayed and truly could not wait to see the story continue onward. Oh happy day when I found out there would be a fourth installment and only a short time to wait.<br />Well the joke was on us. Who wrote this? Clearly it wasn't SM, I couldn't hear her voice in this book at all. What happened to the characters, lobotomies? I felt,(and I'm sure some will disagree)that Jacob was the only one to stay true to his nature, his character. You did a disservice to us all.<br />As it has been stated here, not to mention often, it would be the best idea to never read this, let it end at \\"Eclipse\\", it's not like it's the first book to ever end with a question mark. I only say this because you can't unread \\"Breaking Dawn\\", you can't erase it from your mind. I say let this one go and save yourself some heartache.<br /><br />A note to Amazon:<br />You are going to lose out on Kindle book sales if you repeat what you did with this book.  Because you pushed the release back a day (maybe it was out of your hands), I had to make a mad dash to hell (Walmart) to buy the hardcover. I'm certain I wasn't the only one who was affected by this BS.

She wasn't whiney about it, she was mature and did what she thought would be best not for herself this time around, but others. There is still enough romance in the book between Edward and Bella to keep fans interested. but I feel this book was able to grow the characters to adults and to live together.   I feel really disappointed for everyone who is threatening to burn this book (for lack of better words). We all knew Stephenie Meyer loves happy endings, this was a happy ending. This was the book where people were able to live in peace, no more dying, killing, or revenge. We all have to get a long someday right? 031606792X|5.0|Let me start off by saying that I really liked this book. The baby was an unexpected twist, not one that I necessarily liked, but she made it work. I'm a sucker for happy endings and people being happy, so I enjoyed that. Yes, I said it, let the hating begin.    I understand complaints that Bella got everything in the end, but its a book. Girls reading it shouldn't take anyone in it as a complete role model, set off to become just like them. If authors cared what girls who were reading the book thought, then Hermione from Harry Potter, a strong intelligent girl, would not have ended up with Ron, someone who completely disrespected her person, her intelligence, and her passions. There's no problem learning something from characters and taking bits and pieces of them to shape into your own life, but anyone who can't distinguish fiction from real life, who expects everything to turn out perfect in the end, will be set up for a big disappointment. Books aren't meant to teach people how to act and be, that's the parents job. If kids are looking for role models in books, then its the parents who should be condemned, not a book.

031606792X|5.0|. . . oh well, it's never stopped me before.  I liked this book.  I really REALLY liked this book! Bella and Edward seemed stronger than ever by the end.  I even learned to appreciate Jacob.      After reading spoilers I just knew I'd be revolted by the idea that Jacob imprinted on Bella and Edward's baby (which I was . . . a little).  But when I read it, I didn't feel nearly as disturbed as I thought I would.  It actually explained some things from the previous books.  And now I must admit I'm curious to see how Nessie and Jacob's story will play out.  By the way, I do hate the name `Nessie'.  It seems that Bella did too so I guess I'm in good company.  LOL!      Oh, and to those actually reading these reviews for helpful info- Edward did not pimp Bella.  I read that in a review and was like \\"WHAT!!\\"  The scene in question is really quite short and is not what you think it is.  Edward comes close to losing his mind with worry over Bella; that scene is just one of the ways that fact is illustrated.  To be honest, I ended up feeling pretty horrible about how helpless Edward was at that point.  He was forced to watch and do nothing as the baby killed Bella from the inside(ack!).      Which leads me to my last point: Jacob's POV was interesting.  It helped us see a side of the two main characters (Edward in particular) that we rarely see.  Jacob's POV humanized Edward . . . made him appear more vulnerable . . . more helpless . . . than we've ever seen before from Bella's POV.  It was interesting because we got to see just how much of a struggle it is for Edward to keep his worries, fears, etc. away from Bella.  While Edward is being humanized from Jacob's perspective, Jacob begins to humanize the Cullen's' on his own.  It's cool to see his thoughts go from pure hate to grudging and then easyacceptance.  The resulting Edward and Jacob friendship is great to see.        Overall, I'm happy I didn't let the spoilers dissuade me.  I enjoyed this book.

630522577X|5.0|Years ago I saw the original Broadway stage version with Rex Harrison and Julie Andrews. This film version is more complex, with more in-depth characterization, and is impeccably filmed with many imaginative and original touches. Audrey Hepburn was an attractive Liza, but her singing was done by Marnie Nixon, and her cockney speech at the very beginning of the movie was needlessly incomprehensible. It was a classic Hollywood mistake not to use Julie Andrews in the screen version.<br /> Harrison is brilliant as Henry Higgins, and the supporting cast is first-rate. The musical numbers are well-structured with a flair and zest which shows George Cukor's taste and sensibilities. The movie deservedly won eight Oscars.<br /> The widescreen, letter-box version I found annoying as I usually do. The movie's sumptuous sets seemed to lose out by this process.<br /> The movie is enlightening about the British class system which persists to this day. Higgin's mansion is artfully rendered, and the scenes in which the servants sing are captivating.<br /> This film captures the spirit, the style, and the genius of the musical and provides us with an archival record of the show.

031606792X|5.0|I've read a lot of the reviews, and while I can see where people are coming from, and I do agree that this is an unusual plot. I actually think SM got it Right. Here's why:    1. She develops Edward and Bella into adults throughout the plot. While some think that characters were lost; I think their characters were strengthened to those of real life.    2. SM showed her teen audience the consequences of unprotected sex. Say what you may about the pregnancy being unrealistic, but SM never wrote that Edward didn't have any bodily fluids (if she did, please show me where.) But this novel makes a moral statement about sex, I think that this goes along with SM's themes throughout the book. Choices. Responsibility.    3. I loved how SM made Bella into a hero. She refuses to abort her baby, defying even Edward, something she's never done like this. I think Bella is a hero because she takes control of her destiny. She protects those that she love.    4. While many have noted the lack of sacrifice in the book, I beg to differ. Certainly Bella sacrifices a great deal. She mentions wanting to go to Dartmouth, wanting a little more time, but then that is robbed from her. She almost dies as the consequence of her actions. Almost all the vampires die, ALMOST. I know that many think that this is a cop-out, but I don't see it that way. Breaking Dawn is ladden with anguish and darkness. We all the characters that we love suffer tremendously, but after all this suffering there is a happy ending. Is that so wrong?    5. While many wanted Breaking Dawn to be like the first 3 books, we really wouldn't have been satisfied with that ending. Do you really think that Bella and Edward were going to continue on like they were? This may be fiction, but SM knows her characters well. Their substance in this book grew from a couple who loved to stare at each other, to a couple who shares joy, pain, and responsibility. Perhaps the reason that many fans didn't like the book was for the moral, traditional messages it instills.    Any thoughts? I'd love to hear them.
