0743270754|5.0|Doris Kearns Goodwin delivers an extremely well-researched and fascinating book about Lincoln and his leadership style. You don't have to be a history fan to truly enjoy this book as it is beautifully-crafted and highly readable. It is also filled with loads of interesting tales such as how unlikely it was that Lincoln was elected in the first place, and also how he was continually criticized by the press until the very end of his career. It also gives an excellent insight into the causes of the Civil War, personalities of the generals, and how Lincoln interacted with and motivated the troops.      This will be one of the most meaty and detailed books that you'll read, and this can cause it to drag slightly in places as the author invests just as much research into all of the other candidates that ultimately wind up in Lincoln's cabinet. This causes the book to be a bit slow in the beginning as the reader becomes familiar with all of the other characters, but it pays off in the end as it gives crucial background that foreshadows later events. Overall it is a wonderful book that fully showcases Lincoln's genius, and hopefully provides a model that could be followed by anyone in a leadership position.

031606792X|3.0|**SPOILERS**    This book had all the elements that I expected and at the same time took a very unexpected turn. On one hand, I expected Bella to become a vampire with unusual powers (I even anticipated her incredible self-control and ability to shield others like she was able to shield herself).  I also expected Jacob to imprint on someone since SM is a romantic and likes Jacob too much to not give him his happy ending.  Finally, the confrontation with the Volturi was expected, though very anti-climatic.        On the other hand, I did not expect Bella to get pregnant and I really didn't care for this twist (though it certainly opens the door for future books from Nessie's perspective).  I, too, have heard that SM has stated that vampires cannot have children since their bodies are frozen in the moment that they die.  After doing a little searching however, I found that she has also stated \\"Most human fluids are absent in my vampires\\" (Italics mine).  Since Bella was still human when she got pregnant and technically fluids are not completely absent in vampires, this does not rule out the possibility of a half-vampire/half-human child.      Since I did not anticipate the pregnancy, I also did not expect the changes in the characters involved.  I would agree that some of the characters did not feel consistent to me (especially Bella). I am however, trying to keep in mind that she becomes another person in this book so it is reasonable to expect her character to be different in Breaking Dawn.  When Bella is human, she sees herself as plain and un-extraordinary.  She cannot fathom why Edward wants to be with her.  When she becomes a vampire, Bella is no longer the weak human that Edward will always have to defend.  I think this allows her to finally feel worthy of him and gives her the self-confidence that is absent in the early books.  In addition to these changes, Bella also becomes a mother.  Though not a mother myself, I know that becoming a parent has the abilityto change a person in immeasurable ways and alter a person's priorities.  It is true that this book does not focus so much on the love between Edward and Bella, but that is because there is finally someone else in Bella's life that she loves as deeply as Edward.  I believe the reason Breaking Dawn does not focus so much on Edward and Bella's relationship is because SM is attempting to show the love that exists between a mother and her child - we already know how Bella feels about Edward and vice versa.      Was it how I would have imagine Bella and Edward's story to end?  No.  Did it feel rushed at times?  Yes, but being a 700+ page book, I don't know how much of this was SM's choice or simply practicality and editing.     Are the harsher reviews warranted?  Not in my opinion.      Though this was my least favorite book in the Twilight saga, it wasn't a bad story.   Overall, an okay ending to the series.

031606792X|4.0|The Twilight series has always been a major favorite of mine. They were all of a simple teen romance, altared by the fact that it was shared between a mortal, vampire, and werewolf. When I picked up this book, I knew it was going to be different than Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse. But we can't blame Stephenie Meyer for making an ending that may not satisfy you; how do you think you would cope with ending the Twilight series?    I think she put everyone's best interest in tying up the saga. It may have been strange and unusual, but endings can't always be happy. Honestly, she could not complete the series with another happy-go-lucky twist like she did in Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse.    It was a different style of writing, more mature I think. It may not have been the epic romance battle that everyone was anticipating, but we all knew who Bella would end up with. Don't deny it.    For all you Jacob fans, I'm terribly sorry that you have to cope with the idea that the love of his life is a toddler. It was not what I expected, but then again, this book was completely unpredictable.    All of the facts that Meyer justicfied in Q&As were unjustified in the book. Pregnancies? That caught me by surprise, but I think she wanted to bring out the message to teens about unwanted pregnancies.    Everyone in the book got what they wanted, but the fans surely did not. After reading countless reviews, I can see that many fans were disappointed by this highly anticipated book. It was different, oh yeah. But not everything can be the froofy romance that we want it to be.     The book was not as great as the first three (which I completely adored), but not everyone can have what they want exactly. It was a great series, and I will honestly miss it. Even though people may dislike this book, no one can deny that Stephenie Meyer created one of the best romance and beautiful tales in the world.

B000007OTH|5.0|This 2-CD set of Bruch's 3 symphonies and five violin pieces is a compilation of downright beautiful music.  Bruch's romantic symphonies are exquisitely crafted- chock full of lush themes and wonderful orchestration.  If you're unfamiliar with them (as I was) at one moment you'll be thinking Schumann, then at another Brahms.  There are moments of Mahler-like bombast but fortunately they're few and brief.    The violin pieces are as good or even better- ranging from a virtuosic tour-de-force to haunting introspection.    Both the orchestral and solo violin playing are very well done- no negatives here.  And I disagree with a (much earlier) reviewer- I thought Philips did a nice job with the sound throughout, both in the miking and recording.    If you're a fan of Romantic music, and especially German Romantic music (is there any better?) you'll enjoy this modestly-priced CD set as an addition to your collection.
031606792X|2.0|*Minor Spoilers*  For the most part, I enjoyed reading the first three books in the twilight saga. Needless to say, I couldn't believe that Breaking Dawn was written by the same author who wrote the three books prior to it. It was a letdown and  an embarrassing work of fiction. All the ground rules and character development present in the other books were completely shattered for me in this one. Bella pregnant? Not only does Edward have two more chromosomal pairs than Bella, but she is also extremely frail, even for a human. How did she survive THAT? She is also a horrible role model for girls everywhere. She lacks any iota of independence and her main goal in life was to have a creepy vampire baby, or die trying (all the while ditching an education so she can start a family at age 18). Do I even have to mention the repulsiveness of Jacob imprinting on Bella's vampire hybrid daughter, while simultaneously coming to embrace Edward as a brother when a couple hundred pages earlier he wanted to kill him? This book had an entirely different tone. Darker. Less humor. Her forced happy ending seemed too superficial to be real, and undermined the importance of choice in the previous books. Stephenie Meyer has always said how much she loves her characters. And so she gives them a \\"happy\\" ending. However, in the process, she made me dislike them and the world she created. If you haven't read Breaking Dawn. Don't. Stop now. Save yourself the disappointment. Create a better picture for yourself than the bad fanfic-like novel that is Burning Dawn.
031606792X|3.0|Let me first say that I really enjoyed reading this book. It was a good read, interesting, and riveting up until the final chapter. It was the perfect book to read over the summer. However it was not a good Twilight book. While I did enjoy it, I will not be reading it again, nor really ever connecting it to the other 3 Stephanie Meyer books which I know and love. The first three books were so good that I had high expectations for this book, but it was a different more erratic style then the first three and lacked their depth.       My first problem came with the pregnancy. Ironically the night the book came out me and my cousin were debating whether or not Bella could become pregnant, and I said judging on Esme and Rosalie, if they both wanted children and were unable to have any, the men most certainly would not be able to produce any children either. Also Bella was in no shape to raise a child, and based on her actions in the previous three books, didn't want one either. However in this book she becomes ultimately protective and motherly towards her child, and that is somewhat kind of believable as she is maturing a bit in this book, however what really got me was not Bella's sudden change of heart on becoming a teenage-mother (I mean what the heck? She goes from never wanting to get married early, to thrilled to be pregnant at 18) , but the pregnancy itself. I don't like Meyer's stilted explanation for why the men vampires can reproduce with humans, but the girls can't. If it had been somewhat alluded to in the earlier books then it would make sense, but instead it felt really awkward, sort of like the baby's name (I think it should have been Carlie Renesemee Cullen instead).        Unlike a lot of fans, I didn't have a problem with Jacob imprinting on Nessa. Since we already knew about Quil and Claire, it made sense, and there was a prior example to prepare us. Also while I appreciated the Jacob angst, it was nice to see him get over Bella.        The Volturi epic battle was a bit of a problem for me. At first I thought it had a lot of potential. Here was a chance for the ultimate debate, is a government that keeps control of a dark force but suffers from corruption better than complete anarchy where the dark force runs rampant. Instead of answering or even really greatly addressing this question except in a short speech by revolutionary vampire Garrett, we get a temporary confrontation which answers nothing, and concludes nothing. With an exception of the vampire that turns the Cullens in there are no deaths. There is no epic battle. The Volturi still rule and may strike again at the Cullens. I thought Bella's power was awesome and its power explained because it had been so strong when she when she was human. The ending was just incomplete, and overly happy. It seems like Meyer came up with a great epic battle scene, Vlturi v. Werewolf-Vampire Alliance, and then just had everyone at the battlefield decide to procrastinate the inevitable confrontation which must occur and say thats alright. I think that more than anything really bugged me.         What made the 1st three books so good was the emotional angst each of the characters went through. The angst was adressed in this book, but not with nearly as much skill or prominense, and everything was resolved to quickly and way to happy-go-lucky that it didn't fit. I did want Bella and Edward to find there Happily-Ever After, but less haphazardly. Overall this was a good book to read on a lazy summers day, but it was like the epilogue in Harry Potter, it was nice knowing how everything turned out, but it just didn't measure up to the other three.
031606792X|1.0|As a proud badge carrying member of Team Jacob, I fully expected to hate Breaking Dawn.  My expectations were down, Stephanie Meyer has told us multiple times that Bella would be with Edward in the end (which, side note, wth book author, you don't spoil the plot of your love triangle romance book by TELLING people who she's going to end up with!?) but authors have lied to us before, I still had a glimmer of hope that Bella and Jacob could be together and have a wonderful life.  Well Meyer lied to us alright, just not about Jacob and Bella.    (SPOILERS BELOW)    Breaking Dawn was such a severe disappointment, even for a person who was EXPECTING disappointment, that I'd go right ahead and say this book is not worth buying.  Ignore it's existence!    Bella, who has always been an anti-feminist in her complete inability to rely on herself and how every decision in her life is based on what a boy wants, has gotten worse.  Now, even though she didn't want children, even though part of the reason that made her decision to chose Edward so difficult was the fact that she could never HAVE children, even though Meyer specifically told her readers that vampires couldn't have babies, she's pregnant.  Not only is she pregnant but the half vampire baby is killing her and both of her beloveds think it's a terrible idea to have the baby, but her life will never be complete without it.  In addition all those hardships she'd face because she became a vampire like incontrolable bloodlust and the fact that she'd never see her family again -- completely irrelevant.  Bella is the magical vampire lady who immediately can control the blood lust and she tells Charlie (well shows him) about her being a vamp and he's OK with it.      As for Bella and Jacob?  Well Jacob's still in love with her as we see from 200 glorious pages of his point of view (the only high point in the entire book, moderately well written, sarcastic, and down right funny) but Bella doesn't make one mention of that hardrealization she came to at the end of Eclipse.  That she loves Jacob, too.  That a part of her wants his warm arms around her and not Edward's cold ones.  Then, to make matters worse, after spending half of his point of view complaining about how much he hates imprinting (the werewolf quirk that has one werewolf find their \\"soul mate\\" in any random person, no matter how old they are) and how he would fight it and how he wants to choose who he falls in love with, Jacob imprints on Bella's DAUGHTER (named, laughably, Renesmee Carlie, that is Renee + Esme, Charlie + Carlisle, nicknamed by Jacob Nessie) and he's TOTALLY FINE WITH IT.  DESPITE THE FACT THAT HE FIRST SEES HER WHEN SHE'S ONLY SECONDS OLD.  And the readers are supposed to be happy that Jacob is in love and he gets to stay around Bella.  Who he thought about naked.  And wanted to marry and have babies with.  It's twisted and oedipal and it would be alright if Meyer admitted this but to her it's just one big happy family.      The rest of the Cullens, the vampires we've spent three books getting to know and understand (and in many people's cases, though not this reviewer's) love?  Well they're pushed to the side in favor of the baby plot and a whole bunch of other vampires (whom you can never remember the names of as there are about 30 of them) who show up and each get a page and a half of time.      The pack, that is the rest of the werewolves, are mostly ignored except for a moment with Quil so the reader may re-acquaint themselves with how SWEET and WONDERFUL and NOT AT ALL TOTALLY 100% CREEPY it is for a person to be in love with a 3 year old.  Seth Clearwater gets pagetime because he's the vampire's biggest fans (and therefore an acceptable pack member to talk about) and Leah who was originally feminist and awesome and had spark and spunk?  Well all she wants is a baby, apparently, because she's 20 years old and menopausal.      The humans who we've learned to deal with, like, or love, the students of Forks High School?  They barely get a mention.  Mike Newton, the happy, sweet classmate of Bella who's liked her since they met?  One sarcastic throwaway line (\\"Oh, Mike, how will I go on?\\" Bella says to Edward in response to a question about whether or not she'll miss her human friends, but of course she won't because why do they matter when she can hang out with AWSUM SPARKLY VAMPIRES WITH KEWL POWERZ) and one line about Edward purposefully flinging Bella's garter in his face at the wedding (in a sort of \\"haha I win!\\" statement).  Oh, brother.    All in all the book was a terrible waste of time and money.  If you liked the first three books and don't want to be disappointed, I'd suggest you find good fanfiction (or write good fanfiction) to fill the void Breaking Dawn will leave.

031606792X|1.0|I struggled very hard to actually finish this book.     I love reading, and I consider myself an individual who can branch out and enjoy an array of different things, including books for younger readings. Even though I knew that the Twilight books were not literary works of art, I appreciated them deeply for being not only an addictive, easy read, but for being greatly enjoyable and having a good story that really touched my heart and made me care for the characters.      While many of my friends teased me for enjoying these books, I felt confident standing up for myself and defending the value of these stories.    Not anymore.    I feel nothing but ashamed, after having finished Breaking Dawn.    Not only do I feel embarrassed for having waited in line, screaming like a preteen and jumping up and down until I had the book in my hot little hands, but I'm starting to feel sick about appreciating a book which is advocating so many negative things.    *SPOILERS BELOW, BEWARE*    For one: This book is extremely sexist. I saw these themes in the earlier books, but never so strongly as in Breaking Dawn. Bella is completely dependent on other people, especially the men in her life. Also, Edward has complete control over her sexuality, at one point in the story this causes her to lie and beg in order to make love to her HUSBAND. She is financially dependent on Edward in every way, and she doesn't mind it one bit. Education is completely unimportant to Bella (something that is also reflected in other characters, which is upsetting.) I hate seeing these blatant stereotypes about women, especially when I saw how many young girls are completely addicted to these books.    Two: Racism.  I truly hope that I am not the only person who noticed that most of the non-white vampires were portrayed in a negative light, ESPECIALLY the Brazilian females. They were referred to as the \\"least civilized\\", as \\"wild women\\", and \\"scary\\" to be around. The Egyptian vampires were also cast as standoffish, rude, and willing to betray their friend Carlisle without batting an eye, in order to save their own lives.   Also, when we are inside Jacob's head, she does not make him think in a very intelligent manner. Although his diction and vocabulary made him seem very smart, or at least like he had an education, in the first three books, she seems to dumb him down a lot once we get inside his head. He also does not seem to think twice about dropping out of high school to be with the person he has imprinted on. What is she trying to say about Native Americans here?    As others have mentioned, this book presents a totally unrealistic picture of life to young women. While the books had originally been about choice and the sacrifices that Bella has to make to be with Edward, all of that is negated in this book. She gets EVERYTHING she wants, and doesn't have to lose ONE THING to have it all. A story that was supposed to be about the importance of choices ended up being a story about how in life, you don't have to give up one single thing in order for your dreams to come true.    I would not let my children read this book, and I am sorry that I wasted my time and money on it.

031606792X|5.0|I've been a fan of the series for a while now, but \\"Breaking Dawn\\" tops them all! Her relationship with Edward no longer feels like something cooked up in the mind of a teenage girl, it feels tangible and for lack of a better word, real. This was a fitting end to a girl that we've all come to know and love.  She's no longer a scared, clumsy teen but has instead grown into a thoughtful and, yes, graceful woman.  It's simply stunning!    It is in this reviewer's opinion that Ms. Meyer has done a fitting job closing one story, yet leaving several doors open and ready to be traveled.  I genuinely look forward to whatever Stephenie Meyer creates for us.

031606792X|5.0|I don't think this book deserves the negative reviews--why take what happens so seriously?  Though what happens is certainly unexpected, it didn't ruin the series for me.  I do think this book should be targeted towards those in their later teens--it is definitely the most \\"mature\\" book of the series.    *SPOILERS BELOW*    The biggest shocker of the book is that the unthinkable happens--Bella becomes pregnant with Edward's child.  How is this possible?  I don't know, but apparently SM thinks it is possible, and so it happens.  The vampires in SM's world are not so much blood drinking creatures of the undead, but genetically modified humans.  To me, this makes the idea of a human/vampire pregnancy slightly more plausible.  Vampire rules aren't set in stone.      I've seen several reviews that take this pregnancy as SM endorsing teen pregnancy.  First of all, Bella is married when she gets pregnant.  She and Edward didn't think a pregnancy was even remotely possible.  Of course Bella loves the child.  The fact that she's a teen doesn't make maternal love impossible or improbable.  The fact that she's pregnant with a semi-monster, however, is a bit disturbing initially.    I've also seen people comment about her giving up going to college--let's face it, she didn't really want to go to Dartmouth anyway.  Once she's immortal, she can go to school and get as many degrees as she wants.  Her situation is not a real life one and should not be judged accordingly.    Edward's portrayal in the book was a bit disappointing for me overall.  I think Jacob totally stole the show.  He has strength in times of crisis where Edward sinks into despair.  The whole Team Edward, Team Jacob debate of course becomes moot--especially once Jacob imprints on baby Renesmee (WHY the funky name?  I don't get why authors do this).  I think the people that call this pedophilia are reaching more than a bit.    Overall I think SM did a good job wrapping up the series.  The writing was as concise asever and had the same pull as the other books.  I can definitely see why she didn't want spoilers leaking out before the book's release.  If you're looking for more of the Team Jacob/Team Edward love saga, you're certainly not going to find it in this book.  If you're ready to see Bella come into her own, I think you'll like it.  It is, after all, fiction.  I wouldn't let the negative reviews scare you away--judge for yourself.

031606792X|1.0|I actually cried when I finished reading Breaking Dawn.  All my anticipation and giddy excitement was for naught.    The aspects that made the first three books so appealing were forbidden love, will-they-or-won't-they tension, a good balance between danger and romance, and the dynamic of choice and sacrifice.  I saw virtually none of those here.    *spoiler alert*    Obviously, to have Bella and Edward marry so early in the book eliminates the forbidden love and the will-they-or-won't they tension.  The wedding scene was very happy and I actually enjoyed reading it.  That was about the last chapter I actually enjoyed.    I was deeply disappointed in the honeymoon chapters.  I understand married couples on their honeymoon are rarely PG, but these scenes seemed as if a nice, romantic, PG movie had been edited to show on TV at a G level.  Bella and Edward swim together and then, oh, she wakes up the next morning, having had the most wonderful night of her life.  Would it have been so terrible to describe just a little bit of kissing?    I almost laughed when it turned out that Bella becomes pregnant the first or possibly second time she has sex.  What is this, some sort of abstinence-only campaign hidden in a romance novel?  It reminded me of the scene from \\"Mean Girls\\": \\"Don't have sex.  If you have sex, you will get pregnant and die\\"    Bella, while very mature in many ways, is not the sort of character I would see with a child.  As Edward says in\\"Eclipse\\", Bella takes special looking-after.  Why introduce a baby into that mix when it is so incongruent with Bella's character?  The only reason I can see for including a baby in the story is that, once Bella becomes a vampire, there will be no more damsel-in-distress factor.  A new potential victim is required.    There was no good balance between danger and romance since there was no good romance, as far as I'm concerned.  However, the danger was also difficult to get into.  So the Volturi are coming, and we know frombook two that the Volturi are dangerous.  But the danger factor previously centered around the fact that Bella remained human.  That danger disappeared before the Volturi even think about coming. It seemed contrived to invent a new reason for them to be so dangerous within earlier chapters of the same book.  The danger always felt artificial.    And then when the danger does show up, the reader is lead to believe that a battle is inevitable, since the Volturi have created several layers of offense.  However, once Alice all-too-conveniently shows up with the other immortal, the danger dissipates almost instantaneously.  Where is the layer-upon-layer or offense?  Not to mention that the whole confrontation scene is a very slow and long read.  I was surprised every time I turned the page and the scene still dragged on.    There is no element of choice or sacrifice.  Bella marries Edward, but doesn't seem to feel too badly about it.  In Jacob's book, the reader can feel sorry for Jacob.  (The writing in Jacob's book was better than the rest of BD, but that doesn't say much.)  However, the fact that Jacob imprints on Bella's daughter seems entirely too convenient.  It felt like a cop-out.  Again, the only motive I can see for this plot line is that it gives a reason for the Jacob character to stay in the rest of the book.  With Bella married, there is no reason for him to have stayed in the story.    Another reason there is no sense of sacrifice is that Bella gets everything she ever wanted, no strings attached.  She even gets more than she wanted, with the birth of a child.  She never has to worry about the consequences of becoming a vampire, since she has this super-self-control from day one.  She is even able to maintain a relationship with Charlie.  The character of Charlie served the function of making the romance and the alternate world forbidden.  Now he effectively knows Bella's grand secret that she has been sworn to since book one.      There is nothing for Bella to worry about.  Whose life turns out that way?  The story becomes unrealistic and unbelievable.    The writing in general seemed to be different.  Scenes that should have been one-pagers drag on for several.  For example, Edward feels guilty about hurting Bella on their honeymoon.  Bella says she is fine and had a wonderful time.  That scene dragged out much longer than it should have.  By the end, I was upset at Edward for ruining the memory (that I didn't experience) as much as Bella was.  Additionally, there were few, if any, witty quips.  Previously, Ms. Meyer has included one-liners here and there that actually had me laugh out loud.  There seemed to be none of those here.  And finally, there seemed to be several, what I would call \\"false leads\\".  Jacob becomes friends with Leah.  Why was so much time spent on that and for what purpose?  I was thinking he was going to imprint on her once he saw her in human form.  But nothing seemed to come of that brief story line.  Leah is almost never mentioned again.  The J. Jenks story also seemed to be too complicated for what it turned out to be.      Overall, the book lacked the elements that made the first three books so compelling and spent too much time on non-essentials.  I think it was poorly written and I'm sorry I spent so much time and energy looking forward to it.
031606792X|4.0|Yes, there were things that I didn't like during this book.  But people, hold out for that last book from Bella.  I wasn't let down!
0307269191|5.0|I have placed this book atop my listmania group of literary running books.  Haruki Murakami's marvelously entertaining WHAT I TALK ABOUT WHEN I TALK ABOUT RUNNING is about his running, yes, but it also touches on other interesting ideas, including the author's affinities for music, literature, and baseball, Japanese and American:    \\"As if to lament the defeat of the Boston Red Sox in the playoffs (they lost every game in a Sox vs. Sox series with Chicago), for ten days afterward a cold rain fell on New England. A long autumn rain. Sometimes it rained hard, sometimes softly; sometimes, it would let up for a time like an afterthought, but not once did it clear up.\\"    \\"From beginning to end the sky was completely covered with the thick gray clouds particular to this region. Like a dawdling person, the rain lingered for a long time, then finally made up its mind to turn into a downpour. Towns from New Hampshire to Massachusetts suffered damage from the rain, and the main highway was cut off in places.\\"    Murakami says he took the title of his book from the title of the Raymond Carver short story collection, WHAT I TALK ABOUT WHEN I TALK ABOUT LOVE, and thanks Carver's widow for giving him permission. Murakami has translated many of Carver's works into Japanese, as well as other American fiction. He says:    \\"One other project I'm involved in now is translating Scott Fitzgerald's THE GREAT GATSBY, and things are going well. I've finished the first draft and am revising the second. I'm taking my time, going over each line carefully, and as I do so the translation gets smoother and I'm better able to render Fitzgerald's prose into more natural Japanese.\\"    \\"It's a little strange, perhaps, to make this claim at such a late date, but GATSBY really is an outstanding novel. I never get tired of it, no matter how many times I read it. It's the kind of literature that nourishes you as you read, and every time I do I'm struck by something new, and experience a fresh reactionto it. I find it amazing how such a young writer, only twenty-one at the time, could grasp--so insightfully, so equitably, and so warmly--the realities of life. How was this possible? The more I think about it, and the more I read the novel, the more mysterious it all is.\\"    Music, baseball, literature, and running. My kind of writer.  Runners looking for a similar read might want to try Don Kardong's THIRTY PHONE BOOTHS TO BOSTON.  Readers new to Murakami who enjoyed this one might be inspired to try one of the author's many novels, and I highly recommend THE WIND-UP BIRD CHRONICLE.

031606792X|2.0|While I have been a fan of the first three books in Stephenie Meyer's \\"Twilight Saga\\", I have been a different sort of fan than the books were geared towards. They are \\"young adult\\" novels aimed towards teenage girls. I am a college graduate with a Professional Writing degree. I was able to let my inner romantic teenager squeal delightedly over the first three books and simultaneously able to let my professional eye critique word choices and plot devices. I found \\"Twilight\\" to be well written and very entertaining. \\"New Moon\\" took something away from the series for me--not because of Edward leaving, but because of the sudden introduction of a vampire society and Bella being whisked away to Italy. \\"Twilight\\" had been so grounded in the \\"real world\\" that the scenes in Volterra made me uncomfortable. Eclipse regained some of the solidity of \\"Twilight\\", and I'd hoped for \\"Breaking Dawn\\" to continue the unique feeling of combining an average girl in the real world and vampires.    DETAILED SPOILERS BELOW      Unfortunately, I was entirely disappointed. There was almost nothing of the \\"real world\\" in this book. The beginning of \\"Breaking Dawn\\" reminded me of one of the deleted scenes from \\"Twilight\\" where Rosalie and Alice help Bella get ready for prom. Meyer had removed that scene because it catered too strongly to her girlish desire to describe outfits and decorations. In this book, it seems she emphatically gave in to that impulse. Everything seems like wish fulfillment.   What happened to Bella's distaste of attention and presents seen in the first three books?   Gone.   Instead, she is lavished with gifts and visitors and she never seems to mind. Sometimes Meyer references Bella's dislike of those things, but she never actually shows Bella having that reaction. Bella does little more than roll her eyes, and sometimes not even that, as she accepts the fancy wedding, the honeymoon on a private island, the new cottage with its extensive wardrobe, the jeweled necklace from Aro, and so much more. It's as if Bella's own personality becomes a shadow, mentioned but never seen. I noticed that after Bella's transformation into a vampire, Bella states at what times she would be blushing, if she could. I found this a strange add-on, though perhaps it would have been endearing if this hadn't been the way Bella's personality was displayed throughout the entire book.    I have not participated in the \\"Twilight Saga\\" fandom; I have not read the fanfiction. I do, however, remember a certain term from my younger years where I read a few stories in other fandoms. That term is \\"Mary-Sue.\\"   For those who don't know, a \\"Mary-Sue\\" is a perfect character who has everything, who looks perfect, who all the other characters fall over themselves to adore, and who is completely generic in their perfection. \\"Mary-Sue\\" stories are typically written by teenage girls as wish fulfillment, where they can design a character who has everything that they want. Typically, those stories also contain bad plot devices to put the main character in certain favorable situations and are lackluster towards any details that don't contribute to the adoration of the main character.   \\"Breaking Dawn\\" has two such characters. The first is our beloved Bella. She was so wonderfully imperfect in the first three books. So charming, so average. This is what made the readers care for her. Now, she is extraordinary--but not in the sense that every person is unique and extraordinary in their own way. There is a difference between an ordinary character who becomes extraordinary and a character who is suddenly changed into perfection and given everything they could want. Her personality and her endearing flaws are gone. Instead, she is suddenly faultless. The only flaw we are given is when Bella is looking at her new, vampire self in the mirror and sees that her upper lip is slightly bigger than her lower lip. Other than that, the only descriptions we have of the new Bella are detailinghow gorgeous she is or how strong she is.   Personally, I would have liked to see the world's first clumsy vampire. Who can relate to a perfect character the same way many girls could relate to average Bella? No one read \\"Twilight\\" and decided that they could identify with Edward the most. (In regard to Edward in \\"Breaking Dawn\\", I feel like he was barely there. Merely a bland background character being pulled along the plotlines after Bella.)     The second \\"Mary-Sue\\" is Renesmee, Bella and Edward's daughter. Given great beauty and fantastical powers from the start, Renesmee is less a character than a clich. Where are her flaws? Where are the things that make this child a three-dimensional character? (Or that even make her a child rather than a tiny, beautiful person?) Everyone loves her instantly, she'll be fully-grown in about seven years, and she has met her soulmate immediately after birth. Who is she except a device to miraculously give Bella a perfect child, Jacob a perfect soulmate, and the Volturi a perfect reason to show up again. Meyer has said time and again that these are character-driven books, but her characters faded in favor of plot for \\"Breaking Dawn\\".    Despite the idea that Bella is the main character of this book, several other characters outshine her. Jacob Black, for instance. I was incredibly shocked when I reached the \\"Book Two\\" section, only to discover that we were suddenly reading from Jacob's perspective. After an initial unpleasant reaction, I began to grow used to Jacob's thoughts and soon found his point-of-view preferable to Bella's. Here's a real, three-dimensional character. He was working, he was suffering, and he was also extremely hilarious. (His chapter titles were the best.) His reactions were all very genuine and since these books are expressed to be character-driven books, several plot points made sense for Jacob Black that may not have made sense otherwise. For example, he becomes an alpha of his own pack. It made sense.It worked because the character made it work. We were reminded that this was possible because he was destined to be an alpha anyway. His imprinting on Renesmee worked, in my mind, because we saw Jacob actively searching for someone that he could imprint on. We saw him give up on finding his soulmate, before his soulmate found him. The reader was also aware that the imprinting process would try to select the mate who could produce the best offspring. And on top of that, there was already another case of a werewolf imprinting on a child. These were all things that the reader knew could happen.   This makes the reader's positive or negative opinion on Jacob's imprinting merely that--opinion. Did you like that this happened, or didn't you? The reader does not question the logic this point (though they may question the wisdom) as thoroughly as they would the actual existence of Renesmee.    Another character that had their day was Leah. I was extremely impressed by Leah in this book. She was a minor character, but she was incredibly strong and also very real. Seth was also a genuine character, though perhaps Leah had a little more depth. Her pain and her choices--to join Jacob's pack to avoid Sam and her decision to take human form and yell at Bella--made her understandable and even likeable.   Alice also continued to impress me. Her plan and her sudden disappearance did not seem contrived, though it could have in the face of the other contrived plot points. It made perfect sense for Alice to keep her gift away from Aro, and to leave clues for Bella, the only person Aro couldn't read.   Though Alice and Jasper's reappearance at the end, having somehow magically managed to find another vampire-human hybrid child, was too convenient. It's another example of something, the vampire-human hybrid in this instance, being expressed to be unique, impossible, or forbidden--and yet somehow suddenly exists in spades.    The rules of Meyer's universe are bent for this book. Vampirescannot have children. She had made this point clear. In this book, Edward, a vampire, has a child with Bella while she is still human. How? This doesn't fit with Meyer's own descriptions of a vampire's biology and therefore doesn't make sense.   Why doesn't the baby have a nine-month gestation period? Vampires don't age, so it doesn't make sense that being a half-vampire would make the child age FASTER.   Bella experiences none of the typical symptoms of being a newborn and it's suggested that this is because of her thorough preparation as well as her \\"power\\" of self-control. This could be believable, except that her power is later shown to be shielding, and the idea of self-control is lost. In the final scenes, Bella's suddenly able to master her shielding power right at the crucial moment, when she had not been able to extend it ten feet before.   I did appreciate it that she could later turn her power off, with great effort, letting Edward into her mind.    Of the entire series, I would say that \\"Breaking Dawn\\" is the weakest link. Not to say that this book isn't enjoyable. Wish fulfillment is an entertaining concept and can be very satisfying for a reader. All the good characters get everything they want, and all the bad characters get everything they deserve. However, this doesn't jive with the world Meyer has created, nor does it create any sort of substance.   This book will certainly appeal to some teenage girls, but the older readers will be lost.
031606792X|2.0|I stood in line at midnight and attended the release party...I am so horribly disappointed in the way Stephenie Meyer finished this series - - what a total injustice.
031606792X|1.0|Breaking Dawn finishes wish-fulfillment in a whole new, twisted way.  Not twisted in a -good- way, either.  Nothing is explained about Bella's accelerated pregnancy, the character Nessie comes off as a creepy (this is saying something) Alia from Dune (without being a prophesied genius or anything), and the whole book is hilarious all around (when it's meant to be taken seriously).  Bella comes off as creepy.  Edward, Jacob, and Rosalie all come off as creepy.  There are so many things that happen in this book that go so far off the deep-end of logic, \\"how people actually react,\\" or reality (even in a contrived, sparkly vampire universe), that it's hard to finish this 700+ page book.    Wish-fulfillment, anti-feminist messages, major abuse to the plot and characters (whatever promise they may have -had- was washed away in this book), and the sad part of it is, it's a best-seller.  There are so many other YA authors out there that write well who NEVER get the spotlight like Meyer does (did?).  Meyer lures her fans in because she captures the emotions that many people (women specifically) feel when in the throws of teenaged first love.  And, who wouldn't want their first love to be their one-and-only, true, super-human, beautiful, Byronic hero Edward?    Past that, the shoddy dialogue (\\"Forever and forever and forever\\"?  Come on.  This theme is a dead horse beat a thousand times over, especially with Bella's obsession with suicide--oh, I mean, undeath), horrible messages, Mary-Sue-ism, and the non-climax make this book hilariously undeserving of any praise it gets.

0143038583|5.0|Mr. Pollan's \\"Omnivore's Dilemma\\" is easily one of the best books I've read this year. He approaches the subject of the food we eat, where it comes from and who grows it in a thoughtful and thought provoking manner. He follows the food chain backwards from the fast food joint, the grocery store and restaurant to our food sources. This a cautionary tale about what the American consumer eats and the industrialization of the US food industry. The book is full of interesting characters that inhabit different elements of the food chain. Mr. Pollan's writing is excellent. He has a point of view but rather than beating you over the head with it, he invites you on a journey to discovery. Be prepared to change the way you look at food. AN OUTSTANDING BOOK!! 031606792X|4.0|I would have to say that out of the 4 books, this is my least favorite, but I did enjoy it..devour it. But, maybe I'm coming from a different perspective here. I'm a writer with a world I've created. I dream of it making it to print one day. So, IMHO, with characters who are clearly Meyer's babies, she could only have played this story out the way it played out in her head. Fantasies can be far from rational...they do need rules, but you know what? This is her story...her characters....her fantasy...which she was lucky enough to get published. What I'm saying is...it's not anyone's story to rag on. She ended it the way she wanted to. Her fans don't own her story and, quite frankly, whether you thought the last book was \\"okay\\" or \\"horrendous\\" it's kind of sad to see her fans turn on her like that. I think she's a great writer who wrote her story \\"the way it happened.\\" After loving 3 books, it's rather awful to give vicious (rather than constructive) reviews of a writer you loved just because the 4th book fell short of your expectations.    However, that said...personally (and constructively!) I did get the feeling that this last book should have been split into at least two. I think that would have allowed the reader to take things in a little bit. Personally, I wouldn't have done a whole section from Jacob's point of view (although I LOVED the chapter titles! Hysterical!), but that's only because I'm still mad at him for kissing Bella. A Jacob fan might have loved this section.     As an adult, I should be horrified that Meyer allowed Bella to become a vampire...but, I actually found it refreshing that she let love conquer all and we didn't get a sermon over responsibility, mature decisions, etc.. I enjoyed having a fantasy end as just that...a fantasy. I read a lot of regular fiction and non-fiction. So when I want to read a fantasy...I want just that...a fantasy. I disagree with people who thought Bella was immature or whiny in this last book. Meyer has taken a girl who never thought much of herself, thrown her into hell on earth during the last three books, then made her giddy with happiness in this last book in the beginning and end. I think Bella and Edward's relationship is pinnacle. What teenager hasn't imagined the ultimate love connection? Meyer gives us an \\"on paper\\" example of that \\"what if\\" through Bella and Edward. Therefore, Bella was strong insisting on having Edward's baby....she had enough faith that she could do it. I mean, given their relationship with Edward, how could she allow a part of Edward to be destroyed? Not very realistic in our everyday world, no. But this is a fantasy. Likewise, fans have criticized Bella having a baby at 18. True, not a good thing...but, Bella wasn't living a typical life, here. Even if she never became a vampire, she was involved in a love affair few can attest to, with the opportunity to live her life within the protection, financial security, and care of a coven of (\\"moral\\") vampires. Different set of circumstances. She didn't exactly run off and get knocked up by Johnny Guitar down the street. I also enjoyed watching Edward watch Bella come into her own as a vampire. She showed a strength that came from inside her...in addition to that of her new abilities.    If this were my story, I would have had Bella have lose something. Perhaps Jacob, because, to me, he is a completely selfish character who anyone could stand to lose. It's true that everything did tie up a little too neat. But, I so badly wanted this series to end on a happy note, that I can deal with it. I think the birth scene was riveting. The fact that Jacob imprinted on Renesmee was creepy (and I couldn't get my inner voice around her name), but I got used to it. I got the feeling that she was asked to shove too much material into one book too fast. However, my imagination was satisfied with seeing Edward and Bella live happily ever after. If we could all be so loved!     Thank you Stephenie for introducing us tothe world you dreamed up. Thank you for letting us tag along...and thank you for ending the story the way you wanted to. All writers should be so lucky!

B00005AQE8|5.0|2Pac-All Eyez On Me *****<br /><br />The statement that at least 90% of the time this, All Eyez On Me is the album blasting from the car next to you sounds like hype but the thing is...their right. Recording for this album started the day 2Pac was released from prison. After spending the last year in prison Pac had a head full of ideas; many of which were among his best and most creative of his career.<br /><br />All Eyez On Me is more than just another rap album, it might just be THE rap album. Two discs of solid work. Double albums are a rare art form, and even rarer are the good ones. This is among the best. Released during the death of the genre, it set the standard with it's release.  After 2Pac and Biggy died rap lost it's power. Everyone seemed to give in. Now it is very rare to find someone who says anything. The Game, Kanye, and Common are the few who actually say something with their music while still incorporating the club. That is why rap gets a bad rap these days. While 2Pac prophesied his own death, almost the way Nostradamus would have. He died soon after this album, as did raps golden age.<br /><br />'Ambitionz Az A Ridah' 'All Bout U' 'How Do U Want It' and 'California Love' among other tracks became some of the biggest hits and most legandary cuts in rap radio history. But it is tracks like 'life Goes On' 'Shorty Wanna Be A Thug' and 'Thug Passion' that make the album. They show the lyrical genius of Pac, the poetic brilliance of his mind.<br /><br />If it isn't the greatest album in rap history it is damn close. If Patti Smith was the poetic genius of Punk, 2Pac is her doppelganger of rap, and for that alone the mans work is worth a peak. All Eyez On Me is street brilliance. Highly Recommended.

B000092ZYX|4.0|Radiohead-Hail To The Thief ****<br /><br />What strikes me about Hail To The Thief is that it is Radioheads boldest statement, and yet probably the bands all around weakest album. You find basically the same themes through here as you did there as well. So why is this so bold? Well we always expect Radiohead to go somewhere new and they deliberately didn't. But what is this albums greatest merritt is also it's downfall. There is nothing new here which feels like we have already heard this album before. Though at the same time, In Rainbows only took everything the band ever did and put it all on one album, and I personally feel that it is their strongest album to date, even surpassing the highly acclaimed Ok Computer. So what we have is a paradox.<br /><br />'2 + 2 = 5' with much thought put into this statement, just might be the very best song Radiohead has ever released. It's beautiful melancholy, in a fast angry gun shot to the face delivery with a soft silk screen silohuetted over it. I am aware that statement made no since, that was the point. 'A Wolf At The Door' might be the weakest track Radiohead has ever released making the end of this album perfect. Don't ask me how that works, I don't know. The fact is that everything this band does should suck, because it goes against everything that we are told to like, and maybe that is why we love them so much. In an alternate universe I believe the world hates Radiohead in the same way that we love them.<br /><br />So why not give Hail To The Thief a five star rating, I don't have a reason for that. I just feel that five is too many and anything less than four would be treason. Aside from a few hand claps thrown in nothing new is here as I said making this album feel like you have heard it before. So for that I can't give it a higher rating, and I can't give it a lower rating because all the groups other work is brilliant so it would be hypocritical to lower a rating for that lone reason. 0393324818|5.0|So I'm a big fan of fantasy baseball.  And for those that are as well, you know that playing the fantasy game changes the way you look at everything.  Moneyball has the same effect.  It just revolutionizes your outlook on the game of baseball.  The \\"important\\" stats like RBIs and runs are replaced with really important ones, like OBP and pitches per at bat.  No name guys like Scott Hatteberg become cogs that make teams great.    Michael Lewis crafts a book that is engaging on several levels -- to the baseball fan, the economist, and the statistician.      Ever wonder why we give more credit statistically to a guy that bloops a single just out of a poor fielder's reach vs. the guy that smashes a homerun, but is robbed by an amazing leaping catch?  This book answers those sorts of questions.  And it does so through the amazingly in depth looks at the mind of Billy Beane, the genius that built the A's, renowned for their ability to find talent that other teams miss.      I would highly recommend this book to any fan of baseball on any level.  It's a truly great book, and one that will leave you feeling a bit like you stumbled upon a little known secret.  You'll suddenly rush and start analyzing the latest pickups of your favorite team.  You'll feel compelled to run out and follow the career of guys you'd never heard of before reading the book (and hint...they don't get on SportsCenter that often...).  No regrets after reading this, and I promise it will be staying on my shelf for a long time.

031606792X|1.0|THERE ARE SPOILERS CONTAINED IN THIS REVIEW. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.    To be honest, I haven't even been able to bring myself to finish reading the book, though I do know what happens due to reading spoilers online. I'm just so horrified by what I've read so far that I need to take a break from it. It's corny and overly-contrived and has many \\"WTF\\" elements that make the novel seem like an elaborate fanfiction.    If you are young and idealistic, by all means, read this novel. It's clear that, generally speaking, only readers aged 12-14 could even hope to enjoy this novel - I should hope older readers would be mature enough to realize that the book is not good, and anyone younger shouldn't be reading it. I say \\"idealistic\\" because the novel very much goes in the \\"happy endings for all!\\" direction, which, based on the previous novels of the series, should have been impossible, thus making this novel the most extreme deux ex machina I've ever encountered.    I must warn away anyone that is even the least bit feminist. Throughout the series, Bella has always been a bit of a letdown for a lead female character: She allows Edward to control almost every aspect of her life, and is so dependent on him that it makes me ill. In this novel, the anti-feminism vibe is pushed even further, with Meyer not-so-subtly hinting that all a woman needs to be happy is a husband and babies.     Meyer also conveys an anti-human vibe - by the end of the novel, pretty much all the central characters are some sort of supernatural species, and they all seem thrilled about the fact. It's disturbing, to say the least.    The entire novel was just such a huge disappointment. It completely negated one of the major themes of the series: choice. In Eclipse, Bella faces the choice between Edward and Jacob and, knowing what she will give up (Charlie and Renee, Jacob, the possibility of children, college, etc.), she chooses Edward. That extreme sacrifice was, I felt, the most defining characteristic ofEdward and Bella's relationship. Breaking Dawn completely negates that sacrifice with the many deux ex machina plotlines Meyer introduces, which cheapens Edward and Bella's relationship, which, as we all know, was always the central aspect of the series.    I won't go into any more specifics, but I will say that there were just so many things in this novel that were completely outrageous. When I first read the spoilers, I didn't even believe them. Then when I started reading the novel, I was angry and upset. Now, I've joined the masses that are simply laughing at the novel - we laugh so we don't cry ;)    In conclusion: Read the book for laughs. Don't go in with any high expectations of any sort, because you will be severely disappointed.

031606792X|1.0|Let me start by saying that I loved the book Twilight, and when I heard that there was going to be a sequel, I believed that the series had a lot of promise, and hoped that it would deliver. In Twilight, I was able to forgive Bella for her incessant annoyingness because I assumed, and hoped, that she would grow and develop. I also hoped that there was more to Edward than his unnatural good looks and his limited vocabulary - \\"I love you,\\" \\"You're my life now,\\" \\"I need you,\\" etc. New Moon didn't do any of these things; in fact, the only thing that kept me from throwing New Moon from across the room was the character of Jacob Black. After reading New Moon, I instantly became a member of TEAM JACOB. Jacob just seemed so much more real to me than Edward did. I loved how he had imperfections, quirks and passions that didn't revolve around Bella... which then brings me to Eclipse: I did not understand what Edward and Jacob saw in Bella: she had no hopes, dreams, or plans for her future, aside from turning into a vampire so that she can be with her beloved. She scoffs at the idea of going to an Ivy League University, and claims that she would rather die than be without Edward. I found myself feeling disgusted with the female protagonist that Stephenie Meyer had concocted. I cannot think of a more terrible message to send to preteen girls, the audience that the Twilight Series is aimed at. I also hated how Edward continues to walk on water, and how it appears that he has no flaws. In New Moon or Eclipse, I was hoping that more about his past would be revealed so that I could get more of an in depth look into him.     This finally brings me into my review for Breaking Dawn. I cannot imagine a worse way to end a series that started off strong, and then began to decline. Meyer really could've finished Breaking Dawn off with a bang, with some action and adventure, and hopefully, some more revelation into some of our characters, aside from, say, the human lives of the Cullen family. I wanted Tanya to make an appearance and stir up some trouble. I wanted Edward to stray off the straight and narrow for a while. He would've been more real to me if that were the case. I wanted Bella to be able to experience what the consequences were of choosing to become a vampire, and how she would miss out on many human aspects of life - one of them, having children. Bella becoming pregnant with Edward's child was extremely frustrating for me to read. Meyer completely contradicted herself and felt that it was okay for the rules she had already established for her Twilight world to be broken. I was repulsed with how she felt that Bella was an exception. When Bella changes, she does not seem to experience the consequences - she doesn't seem to go through any pain that the Cullen's went through during their transformation, and she appears completely unaffected by it. I hated that Bella didn't have to give up anything by making a complete lifestyle change. I also find that to be a horrible message to send: that you can get married and have a child at a young age and not have to give up anything. I think it's horrible that young girls are reading that when you make such a drastic lifestyle change, that there are no consequences. Granted, no preteen girl will ever have to make the decision between staying human or becoming a vampire, but they need to understand that the decisions you make always have consequences. Breaking Dawn seemed to completely skip over that issue.     Lastly, I am also very creeped out by Jacob imprinting on Nessie. I find it so disturbing that he is going to end up with the daughter of the woman he loves. Couldn't Jacob have imprinted on another girl, or something? That also brings me to the treaty: I was expecting a full on Vampire/Werewolf War either when Bella became a vampire, or when Bella stayed human. The werewolves would've been mad to see the Cullen's change a human, and the Volturi, I'm sure, would've been furious that Bella hadn't change. This, too, all seemed to be conveniently forgotten.     Meyer had so much potential to end the Twilight series strongly, and to deliver a great book, where there was character development and where she didn't contradict the rules she had established for the Twilight universe - although, I'm sure none of us expected that. I also hoped that this book would've sent a better message, such as, that the choices you make have consequences, and that at times, you have to sacrifice if you really want something. Instead, Breaking Dawn seems to tell young girls that there are no consequences, and that you don't have to give up anything when making a drastic life changing decision, and that in order to be truly happy, you have to marry young, and become a young mother.     This book failed to deliver in every aspect.

031606792X|3.0|*WARNING SPOILERS*    I am torn between loving and disliking this book. What really threw me off was how different this story was from the series. You can feel the connection between the first three books, but Breaking Dawn is completely separated. It's like you can (almost) read this book without reading the first three. At first this confused me, but I figured what it was that made this book so different from the series on which it's based: the maturity level. Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse are adolescent compared to Breaking Dawn. After getting used to the some-what \\"innocence\\" of the first three books I was expecting the same thing from the fourth book. How wrong I was. The fourth installment is considerably more mature and not for the faint-hearted. There is sex, blood, suffering, and violence. When Bella officially becomes a Cullen the story takes a very dark turn. Not that the first three books were dark, but once Bella said \\"I do,\\" to Edward she became completely involved in everything. We are used to the Cullens leaving her out because of her fragile humanity (therefore leaving us readers out of the loop too since we only see Bella's point of view) but this changes quickly near the beginning of the book. The reader is drawn away from the dark life of vampirism and the eroticism of abstinence to the suffering of neverending blood thirst and the hot passion that true love can create.     Oh, what also threw me off was that about 1/3 of the book was from Jacob's point of view. I found it very interesting, but I was more eager to see how Bella and the Cullens were handling the pregnancy from her perspective. Not that there is anything wrong with Jacob; however, this is Bella's story. Stephenie Meyer could have just cut all that out and she would have had more room for character development from our favorite vampire family.     We are also used to the majority of the story being Edward-and-Bella-fluff, however there is not that much in Breaking Dawn.     Overall, I still enjoyed the story. Meyer wrties beautifully (even when describing something bloody and painful), I still love ALL of the characters, and I enjoyed the happy ending. I recommend this book for people ages 15 and up.
